commit_message:
RBD: Add comment about multiattach support

Add a comment discouraging multiattach support
being flipped on without proper investigation and
design.

Change-Id: If9885dd3a2e79af4249418fedfe8f3bf73ad2ef5

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-26 01:20:34.000000000', 'message': 'Implement a skopeo based image uploader

This change allows the tranferring of images between registries and
the introspection of registry images to be performed by skopeo instead
of the docker client. The benefits of using skopeo are:

- images are not stored in the local docker when transferring between
  registries
- registries can be queried for image metadata with out pulling them
  to the local docker
- proper support for valid protocol based URLs when referring to image
  registry locations

The skopeo package is already a dependency of tripleo-common in RDO:
https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/10234/

Change-Id: If27a9e46f0f4649547a61b258ec82c9c67831acd
Closes-Bug: #1708965
Related-Bug: #1694709
'}, {'created': '2017-10-30 22:05:35.000000000', 'message': 'Implement a skopeo based image uploader

- images are not stored in the local docker when transferring between
  registries
- registries can be queried for image metadata with out pulling them
  to the local docker
- proper support for valid protocol based URLs when referring to image
  registry locations

The skopeo package is already a dependency of tripleo-common in RDO:
https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/10234/

Change-Id: If27a9e46f0f4649547a61b258ec82c9c67831acd
Closes-Bug: #1708965
Related-Bug: #1694709
'}, {'created': '2017-11-01 21:52:40.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Implement a skopeo based image uploader

Marking as WIP because it may not be possible to optimise transferring
of duplicate images with skopeo.

This change allows the tranferring of images between registries and
the introspection of registry images to be performed by skopeo instead
of the docker client. The benefits of using skopeo are:

- images are not stored in the local docker when transferring between
  registries
- registries can be queried for image metadata with out pulling them
  to the local docker
- proper support for valid protocol based URLs when referring to image
  registry locations

The skopeo package is already a dependency of tripleo-common in RDO:
https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/10234/

Change-Id: If27a9e46f0f4649547a61b258ec82c9c67831acd
Closes-Bug: #1708965
Related-Bug: #1694709
'}, {'created': '2017-11-12 22:22:51.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Implement a skopeo based image uploader

Marking as WIP because it may not be possible to optimise transferring
of duplicate images with skopeo.

This change allows the tranferring of images between registries and
the introspection of registry images to be performed by skopeo instead
of the docker client. The benefits of using skopeo are:

- images are not stored in the local docker when transferring between
  registries
- registries can be queried for image metadata with out pulling them
  to the local docker
- proper support for valid protocol based URLs when referring to image
  registry locations

The skopeo package is already a dependency of tripleo-common in RDO:
https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/10234/

commit_message:
WIP Implement a skopeo based image uploader

Marking as WIP because it may not be possible to optimise transferring
of duplicate images with skopeo.

This change allows the tranferring of images between registries and
the introspection of registry images to be performed by skopeo instead
of the docker client. The benefits of using skopeo are:

- images are not stored in the local docker when transferring between
  registries
- registries can be queried for image metadata with out pulling them
  to the local docker
- proper support for valid protocol based URLs when referring to image
  registry locations

The skopeo package is already a dependency of tripleo-common in RDO:
https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/10234/

Change-Id: If27a9e46f0f4649547a61b258ec82c9c67831acd
Closes-Bug: #1708965
Related-Bug: #1694709

commit_message:
Disable murano horizon plugin until dep is met

Murano dashboard has a dependency on heat-dashboard which is not yet in
the horizon image. The heat-dashboard was recently packaged in RDO [1]
but hasn't yet made it's way into current-tripleo or current-passed-ci.

We need to add the package into the kolla image once there is a RDO
promotion and re-enable the plugin.

[1] https://github.com/rdo-packages/heat-dashboard-distgit

Change-Id: I7c0ccd915d8429bb348c09ab621163aef275c669
Related-Bug: #1752132

commit_message:
Stop running non-voting jobs in gate

There isn't a need to run non-voting jobs in gate, as it ends up just
wasting CI resources.  Results can be obtained from the check pipeline
results.

Change-Id: Id17185fe699925d849a51a8e2482ef50c93aa229
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit ae58165eadc2fcfbabcf763e7d2995c8d2a330b2)

If apt_repository fails to update the apt cache after updating the
configuration, retries don't register there was a change and so no
attempt is made to update the cache by the module on the second attempt.
This failure can result in a failure to install packages.

This change adds an apt module task to update the cache if the
apt_repository task registers a change. This means updating the cache
will get retried on failure and no longer fail silently.

commit_message:
Fix cache update after initial apt_repository fail

If apt_repository fails to update the apt cache after updating the
configuration, retries don't register there was a change and so no
attempt is made to update the cache by the module on the second attempt.
This failure can result in a failure to install packages.

This change adds an apt module task to update the cache if the
apt_repository task registers a change. This means updating the cache
will get retried on failure and no longer fail silently.

Change-Id: I1d71deeee64fe27df1275965aac8240cc2ab427c
Partial-Bug: #1750656
(cherry picked from commit fe537c7a29ff7022e30771d2f59c00c9bece008e)

commit_message:
Add SELinux contexts for nova log directory

The log directory for nova has the default_t SELinux context and this
prevents rsyslog from accessing nova's logs. This patch ensures that
the file contexts are set properly for nova's logs.

This change also makes nova's log directory configurable using the
`nova_log_dir` variable.

Closes-Bug: 1748911
Change-Id: Iaac69c5807715f50386624602375c89adeeb48a1
(cherry picked from commit 10fc6d9035baf9db11f1b13983dd8df6e0996e4b)

commit_message:
tests: test-nova-upgrades.sh: Drop Ansible verbosity

The upgrade tests are very noisy since Ansible verbosity is set too
high. This makes debugging problems very painful so drop the verbosity
level a bit and let users increase it if desired.

Change-Id: I5fc08aedcee05f01d93af787a2672ee38cdcc40a
(cherry picked from commit a7bf973cd5aff042619ad8295a55b7b8cb10ddb7)

commit_message:
Skip logging for haproxy health checks

The health check requests from haproxy cause uwsgi to write a
lot of useless log lines. This can make it more difficult to find
a problem with a particular service.

This patch adds a route to look for the `osa-haproxy-healthcheck`
user agent string, which haproxy uses when performing health checks.
Any requests with that user agent are not logged.

Closes-Bug: 1742718
Change-Id: I960bf62cfcd1bcbcec4923f04eb7566081b1bec1
(cherry picked from commit 145b98f3298028187f0e151872dcd7d0e54f1353)

[{'created': '2018-02-26 17:04:07.000000000', 'message': 'tox.ini: flake8: Remove I202 from ignore list

Remove I202 (Additional newline in a group of imports) from the ignore
list. I202 is a check from the flake8-import-order [1] package.

There was a note to remove this check once the tempest plugin was
removed. As the tempest plugin has been removed we can now remove the
exclusion of this check.

Update files which failed this test.

[1] https://github.com/PyCQA/flake8-import-order

Change-Id: I6018d5a90174b3d4b6b8d8e05cee1c1104ccfde9
'}]
commit_message:
tox.ini: flake8: Remove I202 from ignore list

Remove I202 (Additional newline in a group of imports) from the ignore
list. I202 is a check from the flake8-import-order [1] package.

There was a note to remove this check once the tempest plugin was
removed. As the tempest plugin has been removed we can now remove the
exclusion of this check.

Update files which failed this test.

[1] https://github.com/PyCQA/flake8-import-order

Change-Id: I6018d5a90174b3d4b6b8d8e05cee1c1104ccfde9

Update heat bootstrap script

This patch set updates the heat bootstrap script to do more than
just getting a keystone token. This specific patch set introduces
two heat-specific roles for heat.

zuul-jobs has multinode playbooks in playbooks/multinode/*, we want
to be triggering multinode jobs against those.

'}, {'created': '2018-02-20 15:32:11.000000000', 'message': "Introduce wait_backoff, fail_if_empty wrappers

* wait_backoff wrapper retries the command several time increasing backoff
  timeout exponentially. Its log is added to to stderr. All openstack calls were
  refactored to to try several time as services may be restarted during
  installation or upgrade.

* fail_if_empty wrapper fails if no output received.

* Some openstack commands were wrapped as there is a deplay between stack and
  resource creation. Usually it's not visible. However, when undercloud is
  located on small VM or cloud flavour is m1.medium then it creates a race
  condition may occur in some places.

Change-Id: If10f4d58f3689bc7d817c8ac2c31e48501e937ce
"}, {'created': '2018-02-21 17:41:33.000000000', 'message': "Introduce wait_backoff, fail_if_empty wrappers

* wait_backoff wrapper retries the command several time increasing backoff
  timeout exponentially. Its log is added to to stderr.

* Under some circumstances (race condition), stack may be created but it's
  resources are not. fail_if_empty wrapper fails if no output received.

* Some openstack commands were wrapped as there is a delay between stack and
  resource creations. Usually it's not visible on speedy environments. However,
  when undercloud is located on small VM or cloud flavour is m1.medium then a
  race condition may occur as heat creates stack and its resources
  sequentially. This means there may be cases when stack is created but its
  resources are not. Wrapping openstack calls with wait_backoff and
  fail_if_empty guarantees output with proper exit code

Change-Id: If10f4d58f3689bc7d817c8ac2c31e48501e937ce
"}, {'created': '2018-02-23 11:21:27.000000000', 'message': "Introduce wait_backoff, fail_if_empty wrappers

* wait_backoff wrapper retries the command several time increasing backoff
  timeout exponentially. Its log is added to to stderr.

* Under some circumstances (race condition), stack may be created but it's
  resources are not. fail_if_empty wrapper fails if no output received.

* Some openstack commands were wrapped as there is a delay between stack and
  resource creations. Usually it's not visible on speedy environments. However,
  when undercloud is located on small VM or cloud flavour is m1.medium then a
  race condition may occur as heat creates stack and its resources
  sequentially. This means there may be cases when stack is created but its
  resources are not. Wrapping openstack calls with wait_backoff and
  fail_if_empty guarantees output with proper exit code

Change-Id: If10f4d58f3689bc7d817c8ac2c31e48501e937ce
"}]
commit_message:
Introduce wait_backoff, fail_if_empty wrappers

* wait_backoff wrapper retries the command several time increasing backoff
  timeout exponentially. Its log is added to to stderr.

* Under some circumstances (race condition), stack may be created but it's
  resources are not. fail_if_empty wrapper fails if no output received.

* Some openstack commands were wrapped as there is a delay between stack and
  resource creations. Usually it's not visible on speedy environments. However,
  when undercloud is located on small VM or cloud flavour is m1.medium then a
  race condition may occur as heat creates stack and its resources
  sequentially. This means there may be cases when stack is created but its
  resources are not. Wrapping openstack calls with wait_backoff and
  fail_if_empty guarantees output with proper exit code

Change-Id: If10f4d58f3689bc7d817c8ac2c31e48501e937ce

commit_message:
Fix typo in configure-mirrors role name when triggering jobs

The jobs weren't triggering when modifying the configure-mirrors role
because we were expecting a change in configure-mirror instead...

Change-Id: I11e0136c316fdcace63ce75bc471e9494d6224cf

that only to test if this is the cause of os-vif issue we're hitting
with older version on kuryr-cni.

commit_message:
Fix castellan-ui release job

Since castellan-ui is a horizon plugin, it
should use 'publish-to-pypi-horizon' instead
of 'publish-to-pypi' as one of its templates.

Change-Id: Id056da57d7d63e6a4ea88eca5c0559349f3d630e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-01 13:07:45.000000000', 'message': 'Stop using connection tracking for ssh connections

There is an issue with newer kernels (it seems to happen with 4.15.x)
that when conntrack is reloaded while a connection has packets in
flight, this connection going forward is neither considered INVALID
nor RELATED nor ESTABLISHED by the stateful tracking. While this is
certainly a bug elsewhere, we can be nicer with the rest by not using
stateful tracking for ssh connections.

Change-Id: I1b20644ce888930cd28d6eaf2c23787315e8199c
'}, {'created': '2018-03-01 19:11:05.000000000', 'message': 'Stop using connection tracking for ssh connections

There is an issue with newer kernels (it seems to happen with 4.15.x)
that when conntrack is reloaded while a connection has packets in
flight, this connection going forward is neither considered INVALID
nor RELATED nor ESTABLISHED by the stateful tracking. While this is
certainly a bug somewhere in the kernel, we can be easily avoiding
this by just not using stateful filtering for ssh connections, as
we accept any connection from anywhere anyway.

Change-Id: I1b20644ce888930cd28d6eaf2c23787315e8199c
'}]
commit_message:
Stop using connection tracking for ssh connections

There is an issue with newer kernels (it seems to happen with 4.15.x)
that when conntrack is reloaded while a connection has packets in
flight, this connection going forward is neither considered INVALID
nor RELATED nor ESTABLISHED by the stateful tracking. While this is
certainly a bug somewhere in the kernel, we can be easily avoiding
this by just not using stateful filtering for ssh connections, as
we accept any connection from anywhere anyway.

Change-Id: I1b20644ce888930cd28d6eaf2c23787315e8199c

commit_message:
Add readiness and liveness checks to CNI.

This patch adds readiness and liveness to CNI. It checks presence
of NET_ADMIN capabilities, IPDB in working order, connection to
Kubernetes API, quantity of CNI add failures, health of CNI
components and existence of memory leaks.

Implements: blueprint cni-daemon-readiness-liveness
Change-Id: I9a4b871d196dbadfed687df93bb3cad97c957bfb

commit_message:
[ci] Try simplify rally-task-at-devstack job

* rally-openstack is not a service, so it should not be enabled
* cinder is a not name of service(it is name of project and they have
  several services like c-api, c-vol and etc). it should be enabled by
  default.
* tempest is disabled in a parent job. hope it will inherit from there
* ceilometer should not be enabled from the box

Change-Id: I14021e068cc0ed8146da93137c2d508d686080ff

commit_message:
remove the make-dashboard command

We will need to fix make-dashboard as part of the
validate-with-object-model series of patches, but we do not use it any
more so let's just remove it instead.

Change-Id: I25a0ccdde3fb0dede967c9008845de6464beeb77

Skip logging for haproxy health checks

The health check requests from haproxy cause uwsgi to write a
lot of useless log lines. This can make it more difficult to find
a problem with a particular service.

This patch adds a route to look for the `osa-haproxy-healthcheck`
user agent string, which haproxy uses when performing health checks.
Any requests with that user agent are not logged.

commit_message:
Fix prep-zanata

We download already on the remote system, so tell unarchive that the
content is there already and does not need to copied over.

The role currently fails since ansible tries to copy the file over from
the local host.

Change-Id: I8b879b976b19ab5672a95db35346cdea8467e726

commit_message:
Use net-config-simple-bridge.yaml from THT

... instead of the one in tripleo-ci.
We're moving out the CI env files from tripleo-ci so we can branch them.

Depends-On: I4255120e12123568a388c75956e6e8d32dec66aa

Change-Id: I5fccc9fa1d96ff7ecb47923751e0db18ae5c02aa

subject: Allow Galera package downloads over HTTP
messages: [{'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-02-22 18:30:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:12:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-22 18:30:08.000000000', 'message': 'Allow Galera package downloads over HTTP

CentOS has a repo configured for MariaDB that uses HTTPS and this
prevents the repo server from caching the MariaDB packages. That
causes significant delays during CentOS 7 deployments/gates since
those packages are quite large.

This patch changes the MariaDB mirror URL for CentOS to use HTTP.

Closes-Bug: 1750665
Change-Id: I2192ade6eb204404fe67d47af063e0e57fbe7d62
(cherry picked from commit e196be20ea53b75799a6b66a0613aaadd856f449)
'}]
commit_message:
Allow Galera package downloads over HTTP

CentOS has a repo configured for MariaDB that uses HTTPS and this
prevents the repo server from caching the MariaDB packages. That
causes significant delays during CentOS 7 deployments/gates since
those packages are quite large.

This patch changes the MariaDB mirror URL for CentOS to use HTTP.

Closes-Bug: 1750665
Change-Id: I2192ade6eb204404fe67d47af063e0e57fbe7d62
(cherry picked from commit e196be20ea53b75799a6b66a0613aaadd856f449)

and also announce that the puppet baremetal templates are deprecated.

Partial-Bug: #1701532
Change-Id: I8fe699488b5676103432bb042b1d994a02917c49
'}]
commit_message:
Switch deployments to containers by default

Most testing is now focussed around fully containerized deployments
so reflect this in the default environment.

We also mark the docker environment deprecated as it now does nothing
and also announce that the puppet baremetal templates are deprecated.

Partial-Bug: #1701532
Change-Id: I8fe699488b5676103432bb042b1d994a02917c49

commit_message:
Import net-config-simple-bridge.yaml from tropleo-ci repo

This file has been used for the containerized undercloud so we can
deploy a simple bridge with os-net-config.

We're moving the environments used for CI into THT, so we can branch
them. This is part of this effort.

Change-Id: I4255120e12123568a388c75956e6e8d32dec66aa

messages: [{'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-02-22 18:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:12:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:18:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-22 18:30:17.000000000', 'message': 'Allow Galera package downloads over HTTP

CentOS has a repo configured for MariaDB that uses HTTPS and this
prevents the repo server from caching the MariaDB packages. That
causes significant delays during CentOS 7 deployments/gates since
those packages are quite large.

This patch changes the MariaDB mirror URL for CentOS to use HTTP.

Closes-Bug: 1750665
Change-Id: I2071b0690778669a81770630f25c3dbfa567c818
(cherry picked from commit 33a8fa0e745a048a1e214df29992a78a1e003427)
'}]
commit_message:
Allow Galera package downloads over HTTP

CentOS has a repo configured for MariaDB that uses HTTPS and this
prevents the repo server from caching the MariaDB packages. That
causes significant delays during CentOS 7 deployments/gates since
those packages are quite large.

This patch changes the MariaDB mirror URL for CentOS to use HTTP.

Closes-Bug: 1750665
Change-Id: I2071b0690778669a81770630f25c3dbfa567c818
(cherry picked from commit 33a8fa0e745a048a1e214df29992a78a1e003427)

commit_message:
Fix overcloud image upload for containerized UC

Use overcloud image upload --http-boot only for containerized
undercloud.

Until we figure out a better way of managing http-boot argument when
preparing the image, let's add a conditional so we only use it for a
containerized undercloud and not for the OVB jobs which seems to not
work as of today.

Change-Id: I52cdcabc420276d05827e361d4189522fed57176
Related-Bug: #1748921
Closes-Bug: #1669186
Co-authored-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

messages: [{'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-02-28 11:06:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-02-28 11:07:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-02-28 12:28:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2018-02-28 14:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-28 11:06:59.000000000', 'message': "Remove unused shebang lines

The package for this installs an entrypoint wrapper, so there's
little point in declaring an interpreter in individual modules.
Further, the existing shebangs misleadingly ran python when we only
intend to support python3. Just remove them to avoid confusion.

Change-Id: I62e761719dbf6c357d5b1564ff21b5722b99722c
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unused shebang lines

The package for this installs an entrypoint wrapper, so there's
little point in declaring an interpreter in individual modules.
Further, the existing shebangs misleadingly ran python when we only
intend to support python3. Just remove them to avoid confusion.

Change-Id: I62e761719dbf6c357d5b1564ff21b5722b99722c

commit_message:
Updated NetApp driver features support mapping

NetApp ONTAP driver supports IPv6 since Queens. This patch updates
the features support mapping tables with this support.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ic5c5f798cad5e4e1627c84c599d2a1bc98a6d427

subject: Stop using ansible-role-redhat-subscription-release Gerrit group
messages:
[{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-02-27 12:01:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-02-27 12:04:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-02-27 13:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-02-27 13:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1 -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-02-27 13:08:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Workflow

removing +A pending Andreas' comments."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-02-27 13:09:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Change is correct but the project is *not* under control of TC and not listed in governance repo.

In the past openstack/releases did not handle such repos.

So, let's wait whether this is the right approach. I'd like to have a +1 by release team on this."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-02-27 13:10:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:04:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

We have asked that this repo be added as official. That does not need to block this for now though, so I think we can go ahead.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-03-02 11:06:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1

Ok, then let me approve again (and if the situation changes, you can revert ;)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-27 12:01:45.000000000', 'message': "Stop using ansible-role-redhat-subscription-release Gerrit group

ansible-role-redhat-subscription-release was created by mistake, we
don't want that. We want to release ansible-role-redhat-subscription by
using openstack/releases.

Change-Id: Ie34b147b88fe5c7797ddc4da20d05b50f056a910
"}]
commit_message:
Stop using ansible-role-redhat-subscription-release Gerrit group

ansible-role-redhat-subscription-release was created by mistake, we
don't want that. We want to release ansible-role-redhat-subscription by
using openstack/releases.

Change-Id: Ie34b147b88fe5c7797ddc4da20d05b50f056a910

commit_message:
Do not set gnocchi URL until clustering complete

Gnocchi was providing its URL to client charms before its VIP was
completely setup. This change checks that an hacluster relation
exists and if so waits to provide its URL until the hacluster setup
is complete.

Depends-On: I23eb5e70537a62d5b9e5e24d09f37519b63a1717
Change-Id: I3a6991ecb4eca8659c08d5c5d00d35b8d22bf79e
Closes-Bug: #1749280

In the pike release we migrated everything to use uwsgi. There is no
need to force everything back to eventlet. This was necessary when pike
was master because in ocata we used eventlet. We don't want to switch
deployment mechanisms in an upgrade. But now that pike is base we don't
need to have any of these since everything is consistent on both sides
of the upgrade.

In the pike release we migrated everything to use uwsgi. There is no
need to force everything back to eventlet. This was necessary when pike
was master because in ocata we used eventlet. We don't want to switch
deployment mechanisms in an upgrade. But now that pike is base we don't
need to have any of these since everything is consistent on both sides
of the upgrade.

With the switch to uwsgi (for most services) just doing a ps and
grepping for the process name isn't as simple as it was when each binary
command was unique. When using uwsgi the command is 'uwsgi' which isn't
unique between processes. Luckily we've also switched everything to run
under systemd which gives us an easy alternative to check if the service
is running. This commit also pivots the checking to leverage systemd to
check the status of the process instead of using ps.

Depends-On: I066f5f87ff22d7da2e3814f8c2de75f2af625d2b
Change-Id: Ib504ab21dfc5e32eb3f73f57d636981963e20520

commit_message:
Ensure we use uwsgi for everything

In the pike release we migrated everything to use uwsgi. There is no
need to force everything back to eventlet. This was necessary when pike
was master because in ocata we used eventlet. We don't want to switch
deployment mechanisms in an upgrade. But now that pike is base we don't
need to have any of these since everything is consistent on both sides
of the upgrade.

Depends-On: I066f5f87ff22d7da2e3814f8c2de75f2af625d2b
Change-Id: Ib504ab21dfc5e32eb3f73f57d636981963e20520

 > I think we don't need to support it.... let's see what others
 > think! I see your point though

For a chassis to be candidate I think bridge mappings is must."}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2018-01-26 07:12:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Let me know if my suggestion doesn't make sense. I can remove my -1 :)"}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2018-01-31 08:37:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I understand your concern and also Dong's, maybe we want to document it in networking-ovn. ovn-controller doesn't include this specific parameter in its doc, instead it defines what 'ovn-cms-options' is used for. We can document this specific parameter (enable-chassis-as-gw) in networking-ovn and then it should be fine.
As for Numan's suggestion I'm fine with that but then I'd split that in two:
ENABLE_EXTERNAL_CONNECTIVITY
ENABLE_AS_GATEWAY

for the 1st one we'd configure bridge mappings and for the 2nd one we'd configure the CMS option. Does it make sense?
This way one could deploy DVR setups for example (although we would need a third option for the distributed floating ips...). Not sure if we'll be making things too complex :)"}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2018-01-31 09:00:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-25 10:57:16.000000000', 'message': 'Schedule gateway on chassis from ovn-cms-options

Admin sets ovn-cms-options in external_ids as

ovs-vsctl set open .
   external_ids:ovn-cms-options="enable-chassis-as-gw"

to enable a chassis as a candidate for scheduling gateway router.
Networking-ovn will parse ovn-cms-options and select this chassis
if it has proper bridge mappings.

This helps admin to exclude compute nodes to host gateway routers as
they are more likely to be restarted for maintenance operations.

We follow this order for selecting candidates
1) candidates with ovn-cms-options and proper bridge mappings
2) if no candidates, then chassis with only ovn-cms-options
3) if no candidates, then chassis with proper bridge mappings

Closes-bug: #1743745
Change-Id: I86fbe27f0b6a9317ad82c2bcf2a0446d118de35b
'}, {'created': '2018-01-26 07:27:36.000000000', 'message': 'Schedule gateway on chassis from ovn-cms-options

commit_message:
Schedule gateway on chassis from ovn-cms-options

Admin sets ovn-cms-options in external_ids as

ovs-vsctl set open .
   external_ids:ovn-cms-options="enable-chassis-as-gw"

to enable a chassis as a candidate for scheduling gateway router.
Networking-ovn will parse ovn-cms-options and select this chassis
if it has proper bridge mappings.

This helps admin to exclude compute nodes to host gateway routers as
they are more likely to be restarted for maintenance operations.

We follow this order for selecting candidates
1) candidates with ovn-cms-options and proper bridge mappings
2) if no candidates from 1), then chassis with proper
   bridge mappings

Closes-bug: #1743745
Change-Id: I86fbe27f0b6a9317ad82c2bcf2a0446d118de35b

commit_message:
use common agent topics from neutron-lib

The neutron.common.topics module was rehomed into neutron-lib with
commit Ie88b84949cbd55a4e7ad06341aab77b286cdc485
This patch consumes it by using neutron-lib's version of the module in
prep for Ia4a4604c259ce862597de80c6deeb3d408bf0e95

Change-Id: I7de0ceeeeee4dc19cfce499dab1697c7e5cc2568

messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-03-01 03:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-03-01 10:29:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-03-01 14:59:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-03-01 20:28:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I'm little bit lost and confused now. Why this patch is necessary if 1ef3ce7ac0ab2598a494e85b8575b0114f562296 wasn't merged yet? And second question: why both those patches are only for stable/queens? Is it not a problem in master?"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-03-01 20:41:36.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Slawek Kaplonski <slawek@kaplonski.pl>

Change-Id: Idf91a45db2de7453d4d822c28f4a71e5ed7c6fdb
'}, {'created': '2018-03-01 10:29:49.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Revert "Make floating IP to be prefered over fixed when looking for IP""

This reverts commit 1ef3ce7ac0ab2598a494e85b8575b0114f562296.

Change-Id: Idf91a45db2de7453d4d822c28f4a71e5ed7c6fdb
'}, {'created': '2018-03-01 14:59:56.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Revert "Make floating IP to be prefered over fixed when looking for IP""

The previous attempt exposed a latent bug in the private ip finding
code. When we get the mac address of the floating ip, we then look for
the corresponding fixed ip to return for private_v4. However, we weren't
specifying fixed before, so we were just getting the first one that
matched. That *happened* to be the fixed ip by accident.

Add in ext_tag='fixed' so that we look for the matching MAC from a fixed
interface.

This reverts commit 1ef3ce7ac0ab2598a494e85b8575b0114f562296.

Change-Id: Idf91a45db2de7453d4d822c28f4a71e5ed7c6fdb
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Make floating IP to be prefered over fixed when looking for IP""

The previous attempt exposed a latent bug in the private ip finding
code. When we get the mac address of the floating ip, we then look for
the corresponding fixed ip to return for private_v4. However, we weren't
specifying fixed before, so we were just getting the first one that
matched. That *happened* to be the fixed ip by accident.

Add in ext_tag='fixed' so that we look for the matching MAC from a fixed
interface.

This reverts commit 1ef3ce7ac0ab2598a494e85b8575b0114f562296.

Change-Id: Idf91a45db2de7453d4d822c28f4a71e5ed7c6fdb

commit_message:
Update cmd2 upper constraint to 0.8.0

This commit updates the cmd2 uppper constraint to 0.8.0. In cmd2
0.8.0, they removed some commands[0] such as `run` which is conflicted
with the stestr subcommand. To keep the consistent behavior, it's
good to bump up to this version.

[0] https://github.com/python-cmd2/cmd2/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#080-february-1-2018

Change-Id: I69cc305b2334641806ac9bb8193b2be5650919df

Add ip link functional tests

This patch adds functional tests for operations like:
* set link mtu
* set link namespace
* set link name
* set link alias

commit_message:
Add healthcheck script for Mistral event-engine

This patch adds a script for docker health check of Mistral's
event-engine service. The script checks existence of service with open
connections to RabbitMQ.

Change-Id: I074f7911e8a41d45249dbbf277138bc80ee3a774

This hasn't been wired up since we switched over to use
config-dowload/Ansible.

messages: [{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-02-24 15:23:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-02-26 09:57:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11085, 'date': '2018-02-26 20:36:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-03-01 22:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-24 15:23:17.000000000', 'message': 'undercloud_deploy: add --output-only option

It is useful to only be able to output the Ansible playbook
for the Undercloud and execute it manually. This allows
one to generate the playbooks in a container, and then execute
them elsewhere on a host machine.

Change-Id: Iff0878e097854823da872af23bcf9a63140791dd
'}]
commit_message:
undercloud_deploy: add --output-only option

It is useful to only be able to output the Ansible playbook
for the Undercloud and execute it manually. This allows
one to generate the playbooks in a container, and then execute
them elsewhere on a host machine.

Change-Id: Iff0878e097854823da872af23bcf9a63140791dd

commit_message:
Stop using --os-baremetal-api-version in devstack by default

We're defaulting to 'latest' in ironicclient now, so only use
it if IRONIC_DEFAULT_API_VERSION is overriden.

Change-Id: Ifa813a9f0980e7d9c65166ef288d0c6f273ba521
(cherry picked from commit f9a88a310a9f75164e83bda6d7c2085618375980)

commit_message:
Allow per inventory hostname per item configs to be merged

This is useful when a specific inventory host has multiple
usages and we need to target specific configuration for a
specific component.

commit_message:
Add validation for rotued networks disabled

Add a validation, if the config have multiple subnets
specified but routed networks is disabled we raise
validation error.

[{'created': '2018-02-19 15:28:10.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Add option to install the Octavia client"

Other OpenStack services clients are being installed as dependencies of Heat. Octavia support in Heat was included during Queens development cycle [1]. TripleO deployments will include python-octaviaclient as requirement of Heat. This means the Octavia client will be installed in the undercloud and overcloud regardless.

This reverts commit fef5be332e25a49bdf68032e5f710a7f99b654df.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bug/1737567+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Change-Id: I727503b6c1acf1953a0ad864ae6288021a745193

This reverts commit fef5be332e25a49bdf68032e5f710a7f99b654df.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bug/1737567+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Change-Id: I727503b6c1acf1953a0ad864ae6288021a745193
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Add option to install the Octavia client"

Other OpenStack services clients are being installed as dependencies of
Heat. Octavia support in Heat was included during Queens development
cycle [1]. TripleO deployments will include python-octaviaclient as
requirement of Heat. This means the Octavia client will be installed in
the undercloud and overcloud regardless.

This reverts commit fef5be332e25a49bdf68032e5f710a7f99b654df.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bug/1737567+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Change-Id: I727503b6c1acf1953a0ad864ae6288021a745193

commit_message:
Use fetch-subunit-output role

Currently there is a zuul-jobs role only used in this tempest job while
other jobs mostly use fetch-subunit-output role.

This changes tries to consolidate towards the most used role, to be able
to clean up zuul-jobs a bit.

Change-Id: I404760ba34767660f8816f48712e13dccad67440
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/548406

messages:
[{'account_id': 22079, 'date': '2018-01-22 12:49:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-22 12:50:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-01-26 14:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Document how to use ceph-ansible with already deployed servers

Update the documentation for deploying Ceph in the overcloud
and for deploying an overcloud to use an external Ceph cluster
when the overcloud deployment is done using already deployed
servers and the ceph-configuration is done using ceph-ansible.

Change-Id: I91eecd03dde89bb0c92ef8a10e3daf21ed4605a8

commit_message:
Add a pcsd_debug option

Add a new pcsd_debug option defaulting to false, in order to be able
to debug pcsd start failures in certain environments.

Change-Id: I2dbd005d685d9d02539c8656248306a1ab5d5538

[{'created': '2018-02-28 16:35:33.000000000', 'message': 'RBD: Improve connection debug statement

When the driver fails to connect to a ceph cluster, having all of the
connection parameters in the debugging statement is of great use in
diagnosing misconfiguration.

Change-Id: I5996efba202891020b859310d31c4efd45817829
'}]
commit_message:
RBD: Improve connection debug statement

When the driver fails to connect to a ceph cluster, having all of the
connection parameters in the debugging statement is of great use in
diagnosing misconfiguration.

commit_message:
Remove unit tests about run_test

This patch remove unit tests about flags, beacuse the flags
about run_test.sh has delete.
About run_test.sh delete, look this patch.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/502120/

Change-Id: Ib0e04ed6d48ec5c52cc62abf59174c313d843792
Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-22 13:40:12.000000000', 'message': "Fix allocated_capacity_gb race on create volume

Because of the stat reporting mechanism used in Cinder and because we don't
update the allocated_capacity_gb in the volume service until the volume's
creation has been successfully completed we have race conditions between the
scheduler's value and the volume's value that may induce the scheduler to
provision more volumes than what it should allow.

This patches fixes this by assuming that the create volume operation on
the volume service will be successful, and thus increases the
allocated_capacity_gb value when the operation starts and reverts the
increase if we reschedule the creation.

Closes-bug: #1751057
Change-Id: Ia321a08d102a9a4f535e46158764cb7f9bc81a9d
"}, {'created': '2018-02-22 14:57:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix allocated_capacity_gb race on create volume

Because of the stat reporting mechanism used in Cinder and because we
don't update the allocated_capacity_gb in the volume service until the
volume's creation has been successfully completed we have race
conditions between the scheduler's value and the volume's value that may
induce the scheduler to provision more volumes than what it should
allow.

This patches fixes this by assuming that the create volume operation on
the volume service will be successful, and thus increases the
allocated_capacity_gb value when the operation starts and reverts the
increase if we reschedule the creation.

Closes-bug: #1751057
Change-Id: Ia321a08d102a9a4f535e46158764cb7f9bc81a9d
"}]
commit_message:
Fix allocated_capacity_gb race on create volume

Because of the stat reporting mechanism used in Cinder and because we
don't update the allocated_capacity_gb in the volume service until the
volume's creation has been successfully completed we have race
conditions between the scheduler's value and the volume's value that may
induce the scheduler to provision more volumes than what it should
allow.

This patches fixes this by assuming that the create volume operation on
the volume service will be successful, and thus increases the
allocated_capacity_gb value when the operation starts and reverts the
increase if we reschedule the creation.

Closes-bug: #1751057
Change-Id: Ia321a08d102a9a4f535e46158764cb7f9bc81a9d

commit_message:
Convert users of tune2fs to privsep.

xenapi likes enabling and disabling ext3 filesystem journals. They can
do that via privsep now.

Change-Id: Iad8198fbd01aa80bde0a6b295963391715c5cd48
blueprint: hurrah-for-privsep

* Rename zuul.yaml -> .zuul.yaml to hide this file from the top level of
  root directory

* Remove all redundant scripts which were used in the old CI

* Modify devstack plugin to print information about Rally-OpenStack

* Add simple task file with one workload to check the single job

* Add an index html page for the new job. It is quite simple, doesn't
  use template, so no need to special script which will make this file.
  Also, we do not need to ship this file with python package since it is
  located in proper place.

* Add a basic job which launchs Rally task based on input arguments:
  - rally_task_file - a patch to Rally task file in relative way to
       project path (project which where the job is launched)
  - rally_task_args_file - an optional path to a file with arguments to
       Rally task. It is also relative to the project path
  - use_existing_users - Defaults to False. Whethere to create and put
       existing users to Rally deployment/enviroment or not.

Change-Id: Ib3b021914ac7d565df05c5397b378037ca0c0b00

commit_message:
Add basic job for Rally task

* Rename zuul.yaml -> .zuul.yaml to hide this file from the top level of
  root directory

* Remove all redundant scripts which were used in the old CI

* Modify devstack plugin to print information about Rally-OpenStack

* Add simple task file with one workload to check the single job

* Add an index html page for the new job. It is quite simple, doesn't
  use template, so no need to special script which will make this file.
  Also, we do not need to ship this file with python package since it is
  located in proper place.

* Add a basic job which launchs Rally task based on input arguments:
  - rally_task_file - a patch to Rally task file in relative way to
       project path (project which where the job is launched)
  - rally_task_args_file - an optional path to a file with arguments to
       Rally task. It is also relative to the project path
  - use_existing_users - Defaults to False. Whethere to create and put
       existing users to Rally deployment/enviroment or not.

Change-Id: Ib3b021914ac7d565df05c5397b378037ca0c0b00

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-09 13:07:46.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I2ecf7a0cdad107ec5421541ac81f809bd2dde89a

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I2ecf7a0cdad107ec5421541ac81f809bd2dde89a

For configuring SRIOV, Nuage code relies on setting monkey patch parameters.
These parameters are available from nova::patch::config class. This change

commit_message:
Conditionally include nova patch config in Nuage

For configuring SRIOV, Nuage code relies on setting monkey patch parameters.
These parameters are available from nova::patch::config class. This change
includes the config class if SRIOV is present as one of the mechanism_drivers.
The change depends on the addition of nova patching configuration parameters.
This approach will not fly for Queens and later due to containerized
deployments, but as of Pike, there is no clean approach of separating out
neutron and nova completely. This review is meant for Pike and earlier
releases only. More info can be found here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/500107

Depends-On: I51ef3e19daff1d98cfe5c2c16475c16e6a3e3e0f
Change-Id: Ic2e912cba51a7dd585e896b785056a281104fd74
(cherry picked from commit 3530b591cd13e219f0b3d6e0fb83507a323c1899)

commit_message:
Conditionally include nova patch config in Nuage

For configuring SRIOV, Nuage code relies on setting monkey patch parameters.
These parameters are available from nova::patch::config class. This change
includes the config class if SRIOV is present as one of the mechanism_drivers.
The change depends on the addition of nova patching configuration parameters.
This approach will not fly for Queens and later due to containerized
deployments, but as of Pike, there is no clean approach of separating out
neutron and nova completely. This review is meant for Pike and earlier
releases only. More info can be found here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/500107

Depends-On: I51ef3e19daff1d98cfe5c2c16475c16e6a3e3e0f
Change-Id: Ic2e912cba51a7dd585e896b785056a281104fd74
(cherry picked from commit 3530b591cd13e219f0b3d6e0fb83507a323c1899)

commit_message:
Generate plugin list for registry document

This commit makes to generate a plugin list for the registry
document and, also fixes a python3 incompatibility and docs warnings
in generate-grenade-plugins-list.sh.
And this commit also removes doc/source/plugin-registry.rst because
it's generated by the script.

Change-Id: I391ca452f2e99e899ded8e4bcb5649a4511a7696

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 15:12:09.000000000', 'message': "Cleanup ContainerBroker.get_own_shard_range

Make use of helper method and stop setting new meta-timestamp in
returned ShardRange.

Setting a new meta-timestamp value in the returned ShardRange was a
little opaque. Now, meta-timestamp is explicitly updated when stats
are reported, and the updated value is actually persisted in sysmeta,
which wasn't done before.

Change-Id: I94f0a6f8e3ab38540e3e1c0e61aec7d0e8a05677

"}, {'created': '2018-02-23 20:30:30.000000000', 'message': "Cleanup ContainerBroker.get_own_shard_range

Make use of helper method and stop setting new meta-timestamp in
returned ShardRange.

Setting a new meta-timestamp value in the returned ShardRange was a
little opaque. Now, meta-timestamp is explicitly updated when stats
are reported, and the updated value is actually persisted in sysmeta,
which wasn't done before.

Change-Id: I94f0a6f8e3ab38540e3e1c0e61aec7d0e8a05677

commit_message:
Cleanup ContainerBroker.get_own_shard_range

Make use of helper method to get own shard range.

Use update_own_shard_range helper and use it to persist
reported meta-timestamps and also when making cleaved shard
brokers.

Change-Id: I94f0a6f8e3ab38540e3e1c0e61aec7d0e8a05677

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 11:21:06.000000000', 'message': "WIP make the minor update for docker idempotent

Via Ic08468854ce92e81cd84bd6c86a6b672b5a9d49b we fixed the problem of
docker being restarted when puppet triggers a change while pacemaker is
up and running. That approach, while more correct than what existed
previously, is still suboptimal because we are stopping all docker
containers even though we don't have to.

Let's detect if applying the profile::base::docker manifest would
introduce any changes and also detect if the docker rpm is going to be
updated. If one of the two conditions is true we need to stop
containers.

This way rerunning the update workflow on a node should be much less
disruptive.

NB: Need to test this

Change-Id: I9176da730b0156d06e2a1ef5f2fcc061e2a6abf6
Related-Bug: #1747851
"}, {'created': '2018-02-26 12:09:41.000000000', 'message': "WIP make the minor update for docker idempotent

NB: Need to test this

Change-Id: I9176da730b0156d06e2a1ef5f2fcc061e2a6abf6
Related-Bug: #1747851
"}, {'created': '2018-02-26 16:42:21.000000000', 'message': "Make the minor update for docker idempotent

Via Ic08468854ce92e81cd84bd6c86a6b672b5a9d49b we fixed the problem of
docker being restarted when puppet triggers a change while pacemaker is
up and running. That approach, while more correct than what existed
previously, is still suboptimal because we are stopping all docker
containers even though we don't have to.

Let's detect if applying the profile::base::docker manifest would
introduce any changes and also detect if the docker rpm is going to be
updated. If one of the two conditions is true we need to stop
containers.

This way rerunning the update workflow on a node should be much less
disruptive. Tested this and correctly observed that the first run did
correctly stopped the docker containers whereas subsequent runs did not
stop containers.

Change-Id: I9176da730b0156d06e2a1ef5f2fcc061e2a6abf6
Related-Bug: #1747851

commit_message:
Make the minor update for docker idempotent

Via Ic08468854ce92e81cd84bd6c86a6b672b5a9d49b we fixed the problem of
docker being restarted when puppet triggers a change while pacemaker is
up and running. That approach, while more correct than what existed
previously, is still suboptimal because we are stopping all docker
containers even though we don't have to.

Let's detect if applying the profile::base::docker manifest would
introduce any changes and also detect if the docker rpm is going to be
updated. If one of the two conditions is true we need to stop
containers.

This way rerunning the update workflow on a node should be much less
disruptive. Tested this and correctly observed that the first run did
correctly stopped the docker containers whereas subsequent runs did not
stop containers.

Change-Id: I9176da730b0156d06e2a1ef5f2fcc061e2a6abf6
Related-Bug: #1747851

commit_message:
Cleanup the host prep role & remove redundant tasks

The LXC-Container-Create role now has the ability to setup all of the
network interfaces using systemd-networkd. Those changes give us a
uniform interface to consume when we create containers and free's the
roles from having to care about specific container interface config.
This change removes our now redundant tasks.

This also ensures "dbus" is available in the base contianer image
which was simply added for consistency.

Change-Id: I9278b1f73e1e0fdf98ab5fbe016a77aeb3f75be2
Depends-On: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Neutron scenario to delete subnets for the same network concurrently

This scenario, executed concurrently, should be able to trigger any IP
allocation race conditions in database layer of Neutron IPAM layer.

Change-Id: Icecfcd255fb83250cb77e8505f6b4846e005725c

[{'created': '2018-03-01 11:09:06.000000000', 'message': "Don't use gnocchiclient during publisher init

We can't create archive policies in publisher init because if it fail
because Gnocchi is not yet ready the publisher fail to load. Ceilometer
will work, but samples will go to nowhere.

This change creates/checks archive policies when we publish a sample for
the very first time. If that fail because Gnocchi is not ready, this
will just retry next time Ceilometer will publish samples.

Fixes #1752420

Change-Id: Ib6b4da54592ad99a4e6561a73473b6c7ec73a21f

commit_message:
Don't use gnocchiclient during publisher init

We can't create archive policies in publisher init because if it fail
because Gnocchi is not yet ready the publisher fail to load. Ceilometer
will work, but samples will go to nowhere.

This change creates/checks archive policies when we publish a sample for
the very first time. If that fail because Gnocchi is not ready, this
will just retry next time Ceilometer will publish samples.

Closes-Bug: #1752420

Change-Id: Ib6b4da54592ad99a4e6561a73473b6c7ec73a21f

commit_message:
Remove unused requirements

yamllint and discover are not needed, remove them.

Note that these are not in global-requirements and thus syncing
of requirements fails. Still, syncing will fail due to salt
and dpath.

Change-Id: I3454a83e42d5e99c9dd76ebf8a89884913a130a3

commit_message:
INFINIDAT: load-balance shares inside network space

Instead of always using the first IP from the INFINIDAT InfiniBox
network space, utilize the export_locations attribute of the share
and return the IPs of all enabled network space IPs.

Change-Id: I2319d574cb95f8cc688e608a7e455743e4e63f93

commit_message:
Use dict.get() when accessing capabilities dict

Many compute drivers override the driver capabilities dict [1]. The
code should be using dict.get() to avoid throwing KeyErrors if the
overriding dictionaries do not have the corresponding keys. If the
key is not found it will be assumed the the capability is not supported
and default to false. This ensures that no drivers are broken because
they are missing a capability.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5251f18d87/nova/virt/driver.py#L124-L134

Change-Id: I1fa04fa110f2c65e10c065c61f2f0f58c1fad646
Closes-Bug: #1746608

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-27 22:20:52.000000000', 'message': "Disable warnings as errors for sphinx

If GENERATE_TEMPEST_PLUGIN_LIST=False, the plugin-registry page is not
generated, and then sphinx fails with:

doc/source/index.rst:69:toctree contains reference to nonexisting
document u'plugin-registry'

Setting the variable to False is a legit use case, used in isolated
build environments like CBS used for RDO packages and should be
supported.

Alternatively, we could make inclusion of the page conditional to the
environment variable value, for example using 'only' directive for
sphinx and passing an appropriate 'tag' as a flag indicating the page is
generated, but setup.py interface doesn't seem to provide a way to pass
tags.

Another alternative would be to generate a stub page with no useful
info just to upease sphinx. I figured it's easier to tweak sphinx
configuration though.

Change-Id: Id174d1679c7b141b0327d8c23d6b14f7db83fae8
"}, {'created': '2017-11-27 22:33:51.000000000', 'message': "Disable warnings as errors for sphinx

Another alternative would be to generate a stub page with no useful

configuration though.

The fix still leaves warnings-as-errors enabled for tox environments
with assumption that if tox is used, the build environment is not as
constrained.

commit_message:
Disable warnings as errors for sphinx

If GENERATE_TEMPEST_PLUGIN_LIST=False, the plugin-registry page is not
generated, and then sphinx fails with:

doc/source/index.rst:69:toctree contains reference to nonexisting
document u'plugin-registry'

Setting the variable to False is a legit use case, used in isolated
build environments like CBS used for RDO packages and should be
supported.

Alternatively, we could make inclusion of the page conditional to the
environment variable value, for example using 'only' directive for
sphinx and passing an appropriate 'tag' as a flag indicating the page is
generated; setup.py interface doesn't seem to provide an explicit way to
pass tags but SPHINXOPTS variable would be handy. Sadly, table of
contents can't be controlled with the directive:
https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/1420

Another alternative would be to generate a stub page with no useful
info just to upease sphinx. I figured it's easier to tweak sphinx
configuration though.

The fix still leaves warnings-as-errors enabled for tox environments
with assumption that if tox is used, the build environment is not as
constrained.

Change-Id: Id174d1679c7b141b0327d8c23d6b14f7db83fae8

commit_message:
Fix the substitution of discovered tag

Specifying prepare --tag-from-label does a full tag discovery but the
results are not inserted into the output files. This change fixes
that.

Change-Id: I2f3ffd4c4f1d844a84fc6d352a26879b0a538c47
Closes-Bug: #1749054

docker image build. This fixes that.

commit_message:
Release Tempest 18.0.0

Tempest 18.0.0 is the release to mark
1. the start support of Queens release.
2. the end of support of Newton.

commit_message:
Revert "Resolve hostnames if needed to allow access in ufw"

We need a new proposal that uses get_host_ip from charmhelpers.contrib.network.ip

Reference: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/542381/

This reverts commit 4896ac5b5b98f66cfe79c3945680ac0ac5dbb2bf.

Change-Id: Idd16369be776a10ac6332d7d8b2ce65f9f1ad972

'}, {'created': '2017-11-28 00:50:14.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

Unify all of the container network interfaces using Systemd Networkd.
This change allows us to have a single way to configure container
networks and to use a process that is already system integrated. Care
has been taken to ensure we're able to cleanly upgrade to using the new
capabilities within existing environments without breaking any feature
compatibility.

It's worth noting that all of the pre/post networking up/down script
options have been converted to systemd "oneshot" services. This retains
the ability to run adhoc scripts post networking available while also
opening up this capability, which used to be ubuntu only, to all of
our supported operating systems.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-11-28 08:54:11.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

'}, {'created': '2017-12-14 05:56:53.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

Unify container network interfaces using Systemd Networkd for ubuntu and
centos. This change allows us mostly have a single way to configure
container networks and to use a process that is already system integrated.
Care has been taken to ensure we're able to cleanly upgrade to using the new
capabilities within existing environments without breaking any feature
compatibility or causing massive container restarts.

It's also worth noting that all of the pre/post networking up/down script
options have been converted to systemd "oneshot" services. This retains
the ability to run adhoc scripts post network availability while also
opening up this capability, which used to be ubuntu only, to all of
our supported operating systems.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-12-14 06:13:05.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

'}, {'created': '2017-12-17 00:09:51.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

Unify container network interfaces using Systemd Networkd for ubuntu and
centos. This change allows us to mostly have a single way to configure
container networks and to use a process that is already system integrated.
Care has been taken to ensure we're able to cleanly upgrade to using the new
capabilities within existing environments without breaking any feature
compatibility or causing any container restarts. SUSE support for
networkd is not implemented yet due to the package being unavailable so
legacy network capability remain but only when deploying on suse. As
soon as suse has networkd available to it we should remove the remaining
legacy network setup options.

Handlers have been added for network connection wait conditions and to
various service restarts.

It's also worth noting that all of the pre/post networking up/down script
options have been converted to systemd "oneshot" services. This retains
the ability to run adhoc scripts post network availability while also
opening up this capability, which used to be ubuntu only, to all of
our supported operating systems.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-12-17 08:38:47.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

'}, {'created': '2018-02-24 06:04:28.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

Unify container network interfaces using Systemd Networkd for ubuntu and
centos. This change allows the role to use a single way to configure
container networks.

Care has been taken to ensure we're able to cleanly upgrade to the new
capabilities within existing environments without breaking any feature
compatibility or causing any container restarts.

It's also worth noting that all of the pre/post networking up/down script
options have been converted to systemd "oneshot" services. This retains
the ability to run adhoc scripts post network availability while also
opening up this capability, which used to be ubuntu only, to all of
our supported operating systems.

> SUSE support for networkd is not implemented yet due to the package
  being unavailable so legacy network capability remain but only when
  deploying on suse. As soon as suse has networkd available to it we
  should remove the remaining legacy network setup options.

> A lot of cleanup has been done throughout the task files and
  templates. In the process of updating the role to use unified
  netowrking a lot of duplicate tasks, scripts, and processes have
  consolodated.

> Handlers have been added for network connection wait conditions and
  to various service restarts.

> The OSA plugins have been added to this role as a dependency. We
  rely on the connection plugins throughout the stack however we were
  doing a lot of workarounds to cater to the possibility of a deployer
  runing this role without them. This change simply adds the plugins
  as a known dependency which allows for a more streamlined setup.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

'}, {'created': '2018-02-24 16:10:32.000000000', 'message': 'Unify container network interfaces with networkd

Unify container network interfaces using Systemd Networkd for ubuntu and
centos. This change allows the role to use a single way to configure
container networks.

Care has been taken to ensure we're able to cleanly upgrade to the new
capabilities within existing environments without breaking any feature
compatibility or causing any container restarts.

It's also worth noting that all of the pre/post networking up/down script
options have been converted to systemd "oneshot" services. This retains
the ability to run adhoc scripts post network availability while also
opening up this capability, which used to be ubuntu only, to all of
our supported operating systems.

> Scripts that were being gnerated inline have been placed into template
  files. This solves a long standing memory consumption issue when
  creating lots of containers. The old shell tasks will now be executed
  from a generated script. While this should also help with debugging,
  the main driver is to ensure better system stability.

> SUSE support for networkd is not implemented yet due to the package
  being unavailable so legacy network capability remain but only when
  deploying on suse. As soon as suse has networkd available to it we
  should remove the remaining legacy network setup options.

> A lot of cleanup has been done throughout the task files and
  templates. In the process of updating the role to use unified
  netowrking a lot of duplicate tasks, scripts, and processes have
  consolodated.

> Handlers have been added for network connection wait conditions and
  to various service restarts.

> The OSA plugins have been added to this role as a dependency. We
  rely on the connection plugins throughout the stack however we were
  doing a lot of workarounds to cater to the possibility of a deployer
  runing this role without them. This change simply adds the plugins
  as a known dependency which allows for a more streamlined setup.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

  creating lots of containers. The old shell tasks will now be executed
  from a generated script. While this should also help with debugging,
  the main driver is to ensure better system stability.

  netowrking a lot of duplicate tasks, scripts, and processes have
  consolodated.

> Handlers have been added for network connection wait conditions and
  to various service restarts.

> The OSA plugins have been added to this role as a dependency. We
  rely on the connection plugins throughout the stack however we were
  doing a lot of workarounds to cater to the possibility of a deployer
  runing this role without them. This change simply adds the plugins
  as a known dependency which allows for a more streamlined setup.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3

Unify container network interfaces using Systemd Networkd for ubuntu and
centos. This change allows the role to use a single way to configure
container networks.

Care has been taken to ensure we're able to cleanly upgrade to the new
capabilities within existing environments without breaking any feature
compatibility or causing any container restarts.

It's also worth noting that all of the pre/post networking up/down script
options have been converted to systemd "oneshot" services. This retains
the ability to run adhoc scripts post network availability while also
opening up this capability, which used to be ubuntu only, to all of
our supported operating systems.

> Our usage of lxc-attach was removed in favor of nsenter to fix a issue
  where multiple lxc-attach commands issued to a single physical host
  could result in a hang.

> Scripts that were being gnerated inline have been placed into template
  files. This solves a long standing memory consumption issue when
  creating lots of containers. The old shell tasks will now be executed
  from a generated script. While this should also help with debugging,
  the main driver is to ensure better system stability.

> SUSE support for networkd is not implemented yet due to the package
  being unavailable so legacy network capability remain but only when
  deploying on suse. As soon as suse has networkd available to it we
  should remove the remaining legacy network setup options.

> A lot of cleanup has been done throughout the task files and
  templates. In the process of updating the role to use unified
  netowrking a lot of duplicate tasks, scripts, and processes have
  consolodated.

> Handlers have been added for network connection wait conditions and
  to various service restarts.

> The OSA plugins have been added to this role as a dependency. We
  rely on the connection plugins throughout the stack however we were
  doing a lot of workarounds to cater to the possibility of a deployer
  runing this role without them. This change simply adds the plugins
  as a known dependency which allows for a more streamlined setup.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Unify container network interfaces with networkd

Unify container network interfaces using Systemd Networkd for ubuntu,
centos, and openSUSE. This change allows the role to use a single way to
configure container networks.

Care has been taken to ensure we're able to cleanly upgrade to the new
capabilities within existing environments without breaking any feature
compatibility or causing any container restarts.

It's also worth noting that all of the pre/post networking up/down
script options have been converted to systemd "oneshot" services. This
retains the ability to run adhoc scripts post network availability
while also opening up this capability, which used to be ubuntu only,
to all of our supported operating systems.

> Our usage of `lxc-attach` was removed in favor of `nsenter` to fix a
  issue where multiple `lxc-attach` commands issued to a single physical
  host could result in a hang.

> Scripts that were being generated inline have been placed into
  template files. This solves a long standing memory consumption issue
  when creating lots of containers. The old shell tasks will now be 
  executed from a generated script. While this should also help with 
  debugging, the main driver is to ensure better system stability.

> A lot of cleanup has been done throughout the task files and
  templates. In the process of updating the role to use unified
  networking a lot of duplicate tasks, scripts, and processes have
  consolidated.

> Handlers have been added for network connection wait conditions and
  to various service restarts.

> The OSA plugins have been added to this role as a dependency. We
  rely on the connection plugins throughout the stack however we were
  doing a lot of workarounds to cater to the possibility of a deployer
  running this role without them. This change simply adds the plugins
  as a known dependency which allows for a more streamlined setup.

Change-Id: I5d3ddcfa11d575648a69a04f2fb30236c2c89da3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
api-ref: fix parameter attributes

parameters used in the PATH modified to "TRUE" from "FALSE" (Optional)

In Stack resources
  resource_name for response is modified from path to body
  resource_type for response is modified from path to body
  resource_status for response is modified from query to body

Change-Id: I92b8355c63faf3dded781505ba87fb43d71f89bc

commit_message:
Remove the "max_fail_percentage" option

This option can cause silent failures which are confusing and hard to
track down. While the intention of this was to allow large scale
deployments to succeed in cases where a single node fails due to
transiant issues it has produced more problems in terms of confusion
that it solves. This change removes the option from all production
playbooks.

Change-Id: I1dcbbf5bc8cc66f11dd8ddc22d2a177c5c0f31f1
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit c2743f5cca1930a553ce9f20b207cb17fa6b763d)
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Drop BRANCH_NAME and CLIENT_NAME in tox.ini

These variables are not used in tools/tox_install.sh,
so they are unnecessary.

Change-Id: Id7fd18f24ee0fcbc65c81c3a23132e866fe56c1c

'}, {'created': '2017-10-04 11:37:32.000000000', 'message': 'Allow the confgiuration of virtualbmc on Newton

The upcoming fast-forward upgrade TripleO feature in Queens will take a
Newton undercloud and overcloud and upgrade these to the Queens release.

One of the initial tasks during the upgrade is to linearly upgrade the
undercloud from Newton to Queens. However due to the removal of the
pxe_ssh Ironic driver in Pike this is not possible with virtual test
environments deployed using tripleo-quickstart that use pxe_ssh.

Instead of attempting to migrate underclouds using pxe_ssh to use vbmc
during this upgrade this change simply removes the various conditionals
stopping us from deploying Newton using vbmc.

This depends on a change to tripleo-quickstart-extras where additional
conditionals are also removed and more importantly the presence of
python-virtualbmc in the relevant Newton package repositories.

Depends-On: I45b7f9b52dbb18d752abf48c6d040f3d5ad37a29

commit_message:
Allow the confgiuration of virtualbmc on Newton

The upcoming fast-forward upgrade TripleO feature in Queens will take a
Newton undercloud and overcloud and upgrade these to the Queens release.

One of the initial tasks during the upgrade is to linearly upgrade the
undercloud from Newton to Queens. However due to the removal of the
pxe_ssh Ironic driver in Pike this is not possible with virtual test
environments deployed using tripleo-quickstart that use pxe_ssh.

Instead of attempting to migrate underclouds using pxe_ssh to use vbmc
during this upgrade this change simply removes the various conditionals
stopping us from deploying Newton using vbmc.

This depends on a change to tripleo-quickstart-extras where additional
conditionals are also removed and more importantly the presence of
python-virtualbmc in the relevant Newton package repositories.

Depends-On: I45b7f9b52dbb18d752abf48c6d040f3d5ad37a29
Change-Id: I184cdb106cb8175aaf7fffcaf518af95ccd0f292

commit_message:
Allow the configuration of virtualbmc on Newton

This would allow tripleo-quickstart deployed Newton underclouds to be
upgraded to Queens as required by fast-forward upgrades and documented
in I184cdb106cb8175aaf7fffcaf518af95ccd0f292.

Change-Id: I45b7f9b52dbb18d752abf48c6d040f3d5ad37a29

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-01 13:08:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix the repo cache folder to /opt/stack

The DEST variable in devstack is fixed to /opt/stack, it cannot be
configured. When using a custom devstack_base_dir also the cache
repo was changed and that breaks devstack since it expects the
sources to be in /opt/stack.

Change-Id: I152b0fd8c585baa27a512849d01fe28eff4a132d
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the repo cache folder to /opt/stack

The DEST variable in devstack is fixed to /opt/stack, it cannot be
configured. When using a custom devstack_base_dir also the cache
repo was changed and that breaks devstack since it expects the
sources to be in /opt/stack.

Change-Id: I152b0fd8c585baa27a512849d01fe28eff4a132d

commit_message:
Do not set ha.available until clustered

The interface was setting ha.available immediately with no gating.

The hacluster charm sets a relation variable, clustered, when it has
enough peers and has setup corosync. This change updates the
interface to react to this setting. Only set ha.available when
clustered is set and True.

Change-Id: I23eb5e70537a62d5b9e5e24d09f37519b63a1717
Closes-Bug: #1749280

Fix rdo, tripleo dlrn url for queens

Currently it was pointing to master, but it should
point to queens repo which exists. This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I7e3f20abffb290a87331d4b4bf7a6234c1acc4f0
Closes-Bug: #1752252

[{'created': '2018-02-20 19:08:48.000000000', 'message': 'Detach volumes when deleting a BFV server pre-scheduling

If the user creates a volume-backed server from an existing
volume, the API reserves the volume by creating an attachment
against it. This puts the volume into 'attaching' status.

If the user then deletes the server before it's created in a
cell, by deleting the build request, the attached volume is
orphaned and requires admin intervention in the block storage
service.

This change simply pulls the BDMs off the BuildRequest when
we delete the server via the build request and does the same
local cleanup of those volumes as we would in a "normal" local
delete scenario that the instance was created in a cell but
doesn't have a host.

We don't have to worry about ports in this scenario since
ports are created on the compute, in a cell, and if we're
deleting a build request then we never got far enough to
create ports.

If an instance is deleted before it is scheduled, the BDM
clean-up code uses the mappings from the build request as
they don't exist in the database yet.

there is no attachment_id bound to the block device mapping

the build request, accessing the attachment_id field raises
