commit_message:
Ensure attachment_id always exists for block device mapping

If an instance is deleted before it is scheduled, the BDM
clean-up code uses the mappings from the build request as
they don't exist in the database yet.

When using the older attachment flow with reserve_volume,
there is no attachment_id bound to the block device mapping
and because it is not loaded from database but rather from
the build request, accessing the attachment_id field raises
an exception with 'attachment_id not lazy-loadable'

If we did a new style attach, _validate_bdm will add the
attachment_id from Cinder.  If we did not, then this patch
will make sure to set it to 'None' to avoid raising an
exception when checking if we have an attachment_id set in
the BDM clean-up code

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/wsgi/test_servers.py

Change-Id: I3cc775fc7dafe691b97a15e50ae2e93c92f355be
Closes-Bug: #1750666
(cherry picked from commit 16c2c8b3ee9d70e928a61ceb1ef5931d40e509a4)

Detach volumes when deleting a BFV server pre-scheduling

If the user creates a volume-backed server from an existing
volume, the API reserves the volume by creating an attachment
against it. This puts the volume into 'attaching' status.

If the user then deletes the server before it's created in a
cell, by deleting the build request, the attached volume is
orphaned and requires admin intervention in the block storage
service.

This change simply pulls the BDMs off the BuildRequest when
we delete the server via the build request and does the same
local cleanup of those volumes as we would in a "normal" local
delete scenario that the instance was created in a cell but
doesn't have a host.

We don't have to worry about ports in this scenario since
ports are created on the compute, in a cell, and if we're
deleting a build request then we never got far enough to
create ports.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/wsgi/test_servers.py

Change-Id: I1a576bdb16befabe06a9728d7adf008fc0667077
Partial-Bug: #1404867
(cherry picked from commit 0652e4ab3d506ea21f1bd80b6802c6df5e7b523e)

In some cases juju 1.25 (with maas 1.9) may return a hostname in the
private-address field breaking the assumption that private-address will
always be an IP address. This patch uses socket.getaddrinfo() to assure

Closes-Bug: 1747516
'}]
commit_message:
Resolve hostnames if needed to allow access in ufw

In some cases juju 1.25 (with maas 1.9) may return a hostname in the
private-address field breaking the assumption that private-address will
always be an IP address. This patch uses socket.getaddrinfo() to assure
an IP address is given to ufw.

Change-Id: I99b0110beed6075164eb549ec2433071af699c04
Closes-Bug: 1747516

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-01 10:47:37.000000000', 'message': 'Update the ssh plugin for selective namespaces

The ssh plugin will now use the `nsenter` command to attach to the
container instead of splitting the command functionality between nspawn
and lxc. With the use of `nsenter` we can now selectively use different
namespaces when remotely executing against a container. A new option was
added to the plugin for "container_namespaces" which is a user provided
interface for passing in the namespaces used to attach to the container.
If this option is undefined the default namespaces will be used for full
container isolation.

Change-Id: I904ee68bbc59a0ee4458401a243246bb3f4c3523
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Update the ssh plugin for selective namespaces

The ssh plugin will now use the `nsenter` command to attach to the
container instead of splitting the command functionality between nspawn
and lxc. With the use of `nsenter` we can now selectively use different
namespaces when remotely executing against a container. A new option was
added to the plugin for "container_namespaces" which is a user provided
interface for passing in the namespaces used to attach to the container.
If this option is undefined the default namespaces will be used for full
container isolation.

Change-Id: I904ee68bbc59a0ee4458401a243246bb3f4c3523
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Support volume migration between different availability zones

Currently volume migration bewteen different availability zones does
not work.Sometimes the users need to migrate volume from one
availability zone to another one. It is necessary to support this use
case.

blueprint volume-migration-between-availability-zones

Change-Id: I856655c66e866261fadc702436f43dde74f2c457

commit_message:
resize image's virtual size

Currently Cinder does not modify image's virtual size when creating a
volume from image, and the volume size is usually larger than image's
virtual size. If a vm boots from this volume, user will find that
the root disk space is not consistent with the volume size, which is
supposed to be. This spec is trying to resize the image's virtual size
when creating volume from image, so as to make full use of the image
volume.

Change-Id: Iff82fd64b2d6d6258a949a084da3417815ea1a67
blueprint: resize-image-virtual-size

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-06-06 11:01:25.000000000', 'message': 'HealthCheck Middleware

Currently Cinder does not have any reasonable means to provide health check
information for example to HAProxy. Any such deployment causes extensive
logging and causes unnecessary operations in the server end (FE. GET request
to / which leads to version check).

HealthCheck Middleware provides <SERVER>:<PORT>/healtcheck endpoint.
This endpoint behaves similar way as it does in Swift. Normal operations
returns 200 OK and if config option disable_path is enabled and that path
exists it will return 503 DISABLED BY FILE.

Change-Id: I0ef8018e5dad4b25635c8ae0f93f1e2ef3b5219a
blueprint: healthcheck-middleware

commit_message:
HealthCheck Middleware

Currently Cinder does not have any reasonable means to provide health
check information for example to HAProxy. Any such deployment causes
extensive logging and causes unnecessary operations in the server end
(FE. GET request to / which leads to version check).

HealthCheck Middleware provides <SERVER>:<PORT>/healtcheck endpoint.
This endpoint behaves similar way as it does in Swift. Normal operation
returns 200 'OK', and if config option disable_path is enabled with
existence of that path, it will return 503 'DISABLED BY FILE'.

Change-Id: I0ef8018e5dad4b25635c8ae0f93f1e2ef3b5219a
blueprint: healthcheck-middleware

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-21 23:36:02.000000000', 'message': 'Add functional test for deleting BFV server with old attach flow

When creating a new instance and deleting it before it gets scheduled
with the old attachment flow (reserve_volume), the block device mappings
are not persisted to database which means that the clean up fails
because it tries to lookup attachment_id which cannot be lazy loaded.

This patch adds a (failing) functional test to check for this issue
which will be addressed in a follow-up patch.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/functional/wsgi/test_servers.py

Related-Bug: #1750666
Change-Id: I294c54e5a22dd6e5b226a4b00e7cd116813f0704
(cherry picked from commit 3120627d9802ceda46c2db387fec8fbc80700338)
'}, {'created': '2018-02-22 18:57:03.000000000', 'message': 'Add functional test for deleting BFV server with old attach flow

When creating a new instance and deleting it before it gets scheduled
with the old attachment flow (reserve_volume), the block device mappings
are not persisted to database which means that the clean up fails
because it tries to lookup attachment_id which cannot be lazy loaded.

This patch adds a (failing) functional test to check for this issue
which will be addressed in a follow-up patch.

commit_message:
Add functional test for deleting BFV server with old attach flow

When creating a new instance and deleting it before it gets scheduled
with the old attachment flow (reserve_volume), the block device mappings
are not persisted to database which means that the clean up fails
because it tries to lookup attachment_id which cannot be lazy loaded.

This patch adds a (failing) functional test to check for this issue
which will be addressed in a follow-up patch.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/functional/wsgi/test_servers.py

Related-Bug: #1750666
Change-Id: I294c54e5a22dd6e5b226a4b00e7cd116813f0704
(cherry picked from commit 3120627d9802ceda46c2db387fec8fbc80700338)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-20 16:30:09.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up ports and volumes when deleting ERROR instance

Usually, when instance.host = None, it means the instance was never
scheduled. However, the exception handling routine in compute manager
[1] will set instance.host = None and set instance.vm_state = ERROR
if the instance fails to build on the compute host. If that happens, we
end up with an instance with host = None and vm_state = ERROR which may
have ports and volumes still allocated.

This adds some logic around deleting the instance when it may have
ports or volumes allocated.

  1. If the instance is not in ERROR or SHELVED_OFFLOADED state, we
     expect instance.host to be set to a compute host. So, if we find
     instance.host = None in states other than ERROR or
     SHELVED_OFFLOADED, we consider the instance to have failed
     scheduling and not require ports or volumes to be freed, and we
     simply destroy the instance database record and return. This is
     the "delete while booting" scenario.

  2. If the instance is in ERROR because of a failed build or is
     SHELVED_OFFLOADED, we expect instance.host to be None even though
     there could be ports or volumes allocated. In this case, run the
     _local_delete routine to clean up ports and volumes and delete the
     instance database record.

Co-Authored-By: Ankit Agrawal <ankit11.agrawal@nttdata.com>
Co-Authored-By: Samuel Matzek <smatzek@us.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: melanie witt <melwittt@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: 1404867
Closes-Bug: 1408527

commit_message:
Clean up ports and volumes when deleting ERROR instance

Usually, when instance.host = None, it means the instance was never
scheduled. However, the exception handling routine in compute manager
[1] will set instance.host = None and set instance.vm_state = ERROR
if the instance fails to build on the compute host. If that happens, we
end up with an instance with host = None and vm_state = ERROR which may
have ports and volumes still allocated.

This adds some logic around deleting the instance when it may have
ports or volumes allocated.

  1. If the instance is not in ERROR or SHELVED_OFFLOADED state, we
     expect instance.host to be set to a compute host. So, if we find
     instance.host = None in states other than ERROR or
     SHELVED_OFFLOADED, we consider the instance to have failed
     scheduling and not require ports or volumes to be freed, and we
     simply destroy the instance database record and return. This is
     the "delete while booting" scenario.

  2. If the instance is in ERROR because of a failed build or is
     SHELVED_OFFLOADED, we expect instance.host to be None even though
     there could be ports or volumes allocated. In this case, run the
     _local_delete routine to clean up ports and volumes and delete the
     instance database record.

Co-Authored-By: Ankit Agrawal <ankit11.agrawal@nttdata.com>
Co-Authored-By: Samuel Matzek <smatzek@us.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: melanie witt <melwittt@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: 1404867
Closes-Bug: 1408527

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/55ea961/nova/compute/manager.py#L1927-L1929

Change-Id: I4dc6c8bd3bb6c135f8a698af41f5d0e026c39117
(cherry picked from commit b3f39244a3eacd6fb141de61850cbd84fecdb544)

commit_message:
django2: Replace django.core.urlresolves with django.urls

(In Django 2.0) The django.core.urlresolvers module is removed
in favor of its new location, django.urls.
It was depreacted in Django 1.10:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/releases/1.10/#id3

blueprint django2-support
Change-Id: I46ab5c325491274b8eaffbf848e5d80f83c2fd26

subject: Overhaul HealthManager update threading
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1297, 'name': 'Joshua Harlow', 'email': 'jxharlow@godaddy.com', 'username': 'harlowja'}, {'_account_id': 2245, 'name': 'Jacky Hu', 'email': 'hudayou@hotmail.com', 'username': 'hudayou'}, {'_account_id': 6579, 'name': 'Nir Magnezi', 'email': 'nmagnezi@redhat.com', 'username': 'nmagnezi'}, {'_account_id': 10273, 'name': 'Adam Harwell', 'email': 'flux.adam@gmail.com', 'username': 'rm_you'}, {'_account_id': 10850, 'name': 'German Eichberger', 'email': 'german.eichberger@gmail.com', 'username': 'german'}, {'_account_id': 11628, 'name': 'Michael Johnson', 'email': 'johnsomor@gmail.com', 'username': 'johnsom'}, {'_account_id': 11816, 'name': 'mike_mp@zzzcomputing.com', 'email': 'mike_mp@zzzcomputing.com', 'username': 'zzzeek'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-20 08:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-20 21:39:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

did you actually identify what's wrong with threads?    threads work great for me and I'd like to know what you found."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-20 23:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

+1 me to'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-20 23:54:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Because of the GIL, threads are all stuck on a single CPU. This means if you're doing operations that block on I/O for significant periods of time, they will increase performance as they can run asyncronously. However, if you're doing operations that have very little actual I/O wait, adding threads actually is just adding overhead and context switches, which when expanded to the number of threads we'd need to use causes the context switching overhead to get very far out of hand and reduce performance precipitously. 

Timing data from a very small example run:

8 threads - https://gist.github.com/rm-you/294b3bd4a282eefd514c7eea8cbeff8d

8 processes - https://gist.github.com/rm-you/5e811a17caaeeb60c50dd14ca8893336"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-21 00:03:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Just a thought, turn eventlet.monkey_patch back on (just for a test) and go back to using the thread pool executor, might show u whether it's really context switching or something else..."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-02-21 00:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The one thing that is harder to prove by just saying threads are horrible is if sqlalchemy (or oslo.db) has some kind of issue.

When u switched to processes u basically forced the following to happen:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/engines.py#L405-L417

Which means that u may or may not have hidden the real issue.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-02-21 00:43:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

A few comments'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 01:01:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Yes, I need to add unit tests.

Josh, where would I turn on the eventlet monkey_patching? Anywhere? We don't use eventlet, but you're thinking maybe oslo_db still does? Honestly I think this is a better approach anyway, because further data seems to indicate that *these* processes aren't very intensive, and the real gains may be coming from allowing them to run *away from* something that's eating more CPU in the main process."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 01:55:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 01:56:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 02:42:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-21 02:56:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Because of the GIL, threads are all stuck on a single CPU. This
 > means if you're doing operations that block on I/O for significant
 > periods of time, they will increase performance as they can run
 > asyncronously. However, if you're doing operations that have very
 > little actual I/O wait, adding threads actually is just adding
 > overhead and context switches, which when expanded to the number of
 > threads we'd need to use causes the context switching overhead to
 > get very far out of hand and reduce performance precipitously.
 > 
 > Timing data from a very small example run:
 > 
 > 8 threads - https://gist.github.com/rm-you/294b3bd4a282eefd514c7eea8cbeff8d
 > 
 > 8 processes - https://gist.github.com/rm-you/5e811a17caaeeb60c50dd14ca8893336

Sorry to keep on this, but OK, you're CPU bound, but when we looked at this the work was just doing a SQL query.  Is the CPU-load occurring within SQLAlchemy ?  Also, the GIL causes slowness because you get no parallelism whatsoever.  the context switches of asyncio are more expensive.   of course w/ processes, you have no context switch overhead you just have the expense of serializing data over them."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 06:39:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 06:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 06:41:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Yeah, so I think there IS something else going on too. Trying to track that down exactly, but I think this is quite useful regardless.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 06:57:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> but when we looked at this the work was just doing a SQL query.
 >  Is the CPU-load  occurring within SQLAlchemy ?

The query itself takes negligible time, so it MUST be in SQLAlchemy? Or, something is blocking... Or, neither of those, BECAUSE:

My most recent theory is that the speedup we see from multiproc is less about splitting out all these processes (because they *are not* CPU intensive), but rather getting them away from something else that is hogging the CPU and starving these very small tasks. I'm still working on tracking that down."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 20:47:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I think this is something we should move forward with just because it is a better architecture and fixes a long-standing bug with the non-stevedor'd drivers, regardless of other factors.

So, did I miss anything? Do we need a releasenote or docs changes?
Any more tests people would like to see? More specific functionality from the logger driver? Any names that need to be changed for consistency/clarity?"}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 22:51:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Deployed this to my prod envs...
Here's an example of what it did to CPU utilization (see the spike from the upgrade deployment and sharp drop):
https://i.imgur.com/jI3v1R3.png"}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-21 23:08:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Note: the above graphs actually show it wasn't something with another busy process... So, I'm back to "thread contention" with context-switches totally destroying performance.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-02-21 23:20:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-22 06:07:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Note: the above graphs actually show it wasn't something with
 > another busy process... So, I'm back to "thread contention" with
 > context-switches totally destroying performance.

what would be most awesome would be if you could get me cprofile stats on when the code in question runs to see if something is really hogging up the time.   i think just if that query runs a lot, since you have a zillion joinedloads in it, just working out that query might be very resource expensive - converting it to a baked query (http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/extensions/baked.html) could potentially whack that overhead down to nothing if that's where the overhead is (which in this case is very possible since the query has an extremely long chain of joins that have to be derived from that * you give to joinedload).'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-02-22 06:54:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-26 09:48:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Well, I know that the actual query (when run directly in MySQL) is so trivially fast that it returns in a time so fast that it is barely calculable. I don't think the query running in MySQL is the problem. Or, did you mean that the *creation of the query* in SQLAlchemy could be the problem?"}, {'account_id': 10850, 'date': '2018-02-26 10:57:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

like that we finally stevedore the drivers'}, {'account_id': 10850, 'date': '2018-02-26 10:57:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-26 14:34:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Well, I know that the actual query (when run directly in MySQL) is
 > so trivially fast that it returns in a time so fast that it is
 > barely calculable. I don't think the query running in MySQL is the
 > problem. Or, did you mean that the *creation of the query* in
 > SQLAlchemy could be the problem?

yes, and if so, this problem could have been solved in about three lines of code rather than an 18-file refactor.  This is why I was advising to please get me a quick cProfile output for the section of code in question which would have been less effort than all the code here.  That said, it seems this patch is making other architectural adjustments for the better, however I can still show you the query optimization as your process workers are still doing too much CPU work.  With confirmation that it resolves the issue I would consider reverting the part of this patch that uses a process model back for threads."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-26 16:00:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

We're not going to revert this. All of these changes are things we need regardless -- the majority of the files and such are related to Stevedore loading the driver's, which is actually totally unrelated and I guess could have been another patch. The fix to make things use a ProcessPool is actually only about 15 lines in one file."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-03-01 14:33:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

just as a note Adam and I spent a few hours the other night trying to work up a reliable reproducer for the thread slowness, and while his envirionment (and apparently that of one other person) seems to show a problem, mine does not, running the provided test script with a real octavia database from Adam's environment I can not reproduce any non-negligible difference between the ThreadPoolExecutor and ProcessPoolExecutor.   So I suspect there is some package difference we haven't uncovered yet in environments, or there is something odd going on in the "futures" package that is Python or OS- dependent in some way.'}]

commit_message:
Overhaul HealthManager update threading

* Switch to ProcessPool from ThreadPool (Python threads are horrible)
* Load the health/stats update drivers correctly with stevedore
* Add logging driver

Change-Id: Icda4ff218a6bbaea252c2d75c073754f4161a597

commit_message:
Change confusing test class names

These names contain 'NoMox', which is confusing when none of our tests
use mox. These were added in the commit that adds Keystone v3 API
support, and the difference between them is that they test Keystone v2
versus Keystone v3 APIs. Name them as such.

Change-Id: I72c300c546e04917bd57be327efd51e93c1d1f09

commit_message:
Add non-voting standard upgrade job

To make it easier to switch the upgrade job to non-voting
temporarily in the repositories which have it, have a
standard non-voting one to switch to.

Change-Id: I22623cb84aa9ad48be10bbeb53ba898e99b17371
(cherry picked from commit 1c3b36b320627db81deadc6428c7a2e295642905)

commit_message:
Remove the policy in code spec lite

Removing the spec lite as we did not do this in queens and this did not
contain the details of refactoring the policies which is under planned
work for Rocky.

commit_message:
Remove periodic translations job

The translations job should only run in master as periodic, as
it's intended to be doing the most upstream work.

Change-Id: If1083aeab1481364af466fb722ce0cf8bc44ce83

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 12:46:13.000000000', 'message': "Fix invalid mock in OSC cluster creating unittest

As '_parse_instance_options' is imported into database_clusters, mocking
destination should be the database_clusters module, not the original
troveclient.v1.shell.

The reason this test passed before this patch is, the return value of
'_parse_instance_options' is not checked, i.e. the mock object is also
useless. This patch also checks how troveclient.v1.clusters.create is
called to ensure '_parse_instance_options' is correctly mocked.

Change-Id: I903a3b9565e4044c33401a6abcc47d50a5a2567f
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix invalid mock in OSC cluster creating unittest

As '_parse_instance_options' is imported into database_clusters, mocking
destination should be the database_clusters module, not the original
troveclient.v1.shell.

The reason this test passed before this patch is, the return value of
'_parse_instance_options' is not checked, i.e. the mock object is also
useless. This patch also checks how troveclient.v1.clusters.create is
called to ensure '_parse_instance_options' is correctly mocked.

Change-Id: I903a3b9565e4044c33401a6abcc47d50a5a2567f
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

[{'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-11-29 15:32:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-11-29 15:34:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-11-29 15:46:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Dimitris/Manuel, This is just a initial review to give glimpse on how quagga will get installed. it should undergo into more changes.
Please do the review and let me know your comments. Once it gets into proper shape, then I can invite others for review :)'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-11-29 15:47:37.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to os-setup-bgp-odl'}, {'account_id': 21883, 'date': '2017-11-30 09:03:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

You should not add this to the openstack-ansible repo. You should add this to the os-neutron-repo. The BGP installation should be one file (e.g. bgp-odl-install.yml) which is called from the opendaylight_config.yml playbook depending on a variable (e.g. bgp-odl: True):


- include: bgp-odl-install.yml
  when: bgp-odl == True

That bgp-odl-install.yml should have the different plays which will set everything: installs bgp packages, sets the congif of ODL, etc. To configure ODL correctly, check for example how I am doing it for SFC ==> https://review.openstack.org/#/c/510909/'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-11-30 10:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

You should not add this to the openstack-ansible repo. You should add this to the os-neutron-repo. The BGP installation should be one file (e.g. bgp-odl-install.yml) which is called from the opendaylight_config.yml playbook depending on a variable (e.g. bgp-odl: True):

- include: bgp-odl-install.yml
  when: bgp-odl == True
That bgp-odl-install.yml should have the different plays which will set everything: installs bgp packages, sets the congif of ODL, etc. 

>> As per my discussion with Dimitros and Jean-Philippe, Quagga installation should be in different playbook in osa which would get executed after neutron install  so once neutron playbook configures neutron server with neutron bgp driver and ODL (odl-netvirt-openstack feature), then os-setup-bgp-odl playbook installs quagga and configures ODL for bgpvpn.

To configure ODL correctly, check for example how I am doing it for SFC ==> https://review.openstack.org/#/c/510909/

>> The ODL configuration for bgp is bit different from /c/510909. The karaf feature odl-netvirt-openstack already includes bundles needed for bgpvpn, we just have to run the following karaf command to make it as bgp speaker.
bgp-connect -p 7644 -h 127.0.0.1 add
odl:configure-bgp -op start-bgp-server --as-num 100 --router-id <odl-ip-address>'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-12-01 03:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-12-04 10:17:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Jean-Philippe/Dimitrios: since quagga is tightly integrated with ODL, i would say it is appropriate to keep quagga related configuation in neutron role. I don't have much idea on it can be still used by BaBPipe, OpenContrail etc. Please let me know your thoughts."}, {'account_id': 25505, 'date': '2017-12-06 08:29:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Jean-Philippe/Dimitrios: since quagga is tightly integrated with
 > ODL, i would say it is appropriate to keep quagga related
 > configuation in neutron role. I don't have much idea on it can be
 > still used by BaBPipe, OpenContrail etc. Please let me know your
 > thoughts.

IMHO I think that a new playbook is essential here because there are tasks that would be better not be in the neutron role such as the configuration of ODL as BGP speaker which requires to run some plain comands from karaf CLI.  

Also I think adds flexibility to create a new role for quagga installation."}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-12-06 09:16:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Does it mean OSA would have "os-setup-bgp-odl" playbook, but logic for installing quagga and configuration of ODL is provided from a new role ansible-opendaylight to this playbook ?'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-12-06 09:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I meant a new role in ansible-opendaylight repo (https://github.com/opendaylight/integration-packaging-ansible-opendaylight)'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-12-11 16:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2017-12-11 16:37:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2018-01-15 15:02:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2018-01-15 15:04:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2018-01-15 15:07:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

> (1 comment)

For local deb packages you need to use the 'deb' option
http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/apt_module.html

So you end up with something like

    - name: Install Quagga packages
      package:
        name: "{{ (ansible_pkg_mgr=='apt') | ternary('', temp_quagga_dir }}/{{ item }})"
        deb: "{{ (ansible_pkg_mgr=='apt') | ternary(temp_quagga_dir }}/{{ item }}, '')"
        state: present
      with_items: "{{ quagga_packages.stdout_lines }}"

But what Jean-Philippe said also makes sense. Maybe that should be a role in the end similar to etcd, keepalived etc. Not sure about that...'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-02-15 07:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

1. It adds os_quagga role which is executed from quagga playbook if
bgpvpn depolyment option is chosen
2. Quagga packages are kept as tar.gz package in remote location,
downloaded/extracted/configured as local distribution repository
(apt/yum/zypper) accordingly to install the Quagga and its dependent
packages seamlessly

as BGP speaker for OpenDaylight in one of the neutron server node in
cluster environment.
4. An experimenter zuul job is added to validate the quagga installation

commit_message:
Make Opendaylight as the BGP speaker with 6WIND Quagga

1. It adds os_quagga role which is executed from quagga playbook if
bgpvpn depolyment option is chosen
2. Quagga packages are kept as tar.gz package in remote location,
downloaded/extracted/configured as local distribution repository
(apt/yum/zypper) accordingly to install the Quagga and its dependent
packages seamlessly
3. Quagga to be installed on the neutron server nodes, but its configued
as BGP speaker for OpenDaylight in one of the neutron server node in
cluster environment.
4. An experimenter zuul job is added to validate the quagga installation

Change-Id: I96e76788a76b6e0c2e8000af4516d1998f9de23b
Signed-off-by: Periyasamy Palanisamy <periyasamy.palanisamy@ericsson.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-27 16:50:52.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround glitchy container stats in probe test after shrinking

The root container stats can temporarily glitch during shrinking.
The stats will settle down after sharders are cycled but this can
mean that the probe test intermittently fails to delete the root
container because the root thinks it still has objects.

Removing the update from donor shard might reduce the glitchiness
but would add more delay to root finding out that shrink has
completed. So for time being workaround by adding one more sharder
cycle to the probe test.

Change-Id: I27fba5026bf8fe45edc2db7932573bb84fc65208
'}, {'created': '2018-02-28 13:29:57.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround glitchy container stats in probe test after shrinking

The root container stats can temporarily glitch during shrinking.
The stats will settle down after sharders are cycled but this can
mean that the probe test intermittently fails to delete the root
container because the root thinks it still has objects.

Removing the update from donor shard might reduce the glitchiness
but would add more delay to root finding out that shrink has
completed.

By only running sharder on shard containers we get the stats
update while avoiding the root container triggering any
shrinking.

Change-Id: I27fba5026bf8fe45edc2db7932573bb84fc65208

Change-Id: I27fba5026bf8fe45edc2db7932573bb84fc65208
'}]
commit_message:
Workaround glitchy container stats in probe test after shrinking

The root container stats can temporarily glitch during shrinking.
The stats will settle down after sharders are cycled but this can
mean that the probe test intermittently fails to delete the root
container because the root thinks it still has objects.

Removing the update from donor shard might reduce the glitchiness
but would add more delay to root finding out that shrink has
completed.

By only running sharder on shard containers we get the stats
update while avoiding the root container triggering any
shrinking.

Change-Id: I27fba5026bf8fe45edc2db7932573bb84fc65208

commit_message:
Enable native mode for ScaleIO volumes

Native AIO mode is beneficial for ScaleIO volumes;
performance is slightly better and it utilizes fewer host
resources.

Change-Id: I1cd8742481a17536d906e2bf130e4958ef181ea0

subject: Prepare t-h-t for undercloud in a work dir
messages: [{'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-03-01 12:42:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-03-01 12:59:53.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nsubmitted with wrong changeid'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-01 12:42:03.000000000', 'message': "Prepare t-h-t for undercloud in a work dir

The issue here is that the undercloud heat installer
default uses template in /usr/share and renders the
result of the process-templates.py in place.

Process templates in a temporary work dir created
from the source --templates dir under the --output-dir.
Delete it after the undercloud deployment done, or failed
with an exception, unless --no-cleanup is specified.
Ensure the --output-dir exists for all of the cases.

The --output-dir and --no-cleanup may be passed
either as the 'undercloud deploy' CLI args, or via
the undercloud.conf file, as output_dir and no_cleanup.
The latter way only works for 'undercloud install --use-heat'.

Also, share process_multiple_environments in utils lib.
Reuse the shared process_multiple_environments for
undercloud and overcloud heat installers and add unit tests.

Additionally, fix the shared process_multiple_environments
redirect/rewrite: only redirect and rewrite paths, if fully
matched.

Closes-Bug: #1752272
Closes-Bug: #1749683
Change-Id: Ib0c2e3ffd81742441400d27857afae457d71a424
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I68ffbbfc84ea360880e776f44c45c9fed72bb29f
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Prepare t-h-t for undercloud in a work dir

The issue here is that the undercloud heat installer
default uses template in /usr/share and renders the
result of the process-templates.py in place.

Process templates in a temporary work dir created
from the source --templates dir under the --output-dir.
Delete it after the undercloud deployment done, or failed
with an exception, unless --no-cleanup is specified.
Ensure the --output-dir exists for all of the cases.

The --output-dir and --no-cleanup may be passed
either as the 'undercloud deploy' CLI args, or via
the undercloud.conf file, as output_dir and no_cleanup.
The latter way only works for 'undercloud install --use-heat'.

Also, share process_multiple_environments in utils lib.
Reuse the shared process_multiple_environments for
undercloud and overcloud heat installers and add unit tests.

Additionally, fix the shared process_multiple_environments
redirect/rewrite: only redirect and rewrite paths, if fully
matched.

Closes-Bug: #1752272
Closes-Bug: #1749683
Change-Id: Ib0c2e3ffd81742441400d27857afae457d71a424
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I68ffbbfc84ea360880e776f44c45c9fed72bb29f

commit_message:
[placement] api-ref: Fix a missing response code

In "List resource providers" API,
a 400 badRequest is missing in API reference.
So add it.

Change-Id: I92fcbd6bc1477dd0fe6554c0ba631b9cb7d6fa53
Closes-Bug: #1750728

commit_message:
Remove warning in feature support matrix page

The feature classification effectively died with OSIC, so
let's remove the warning from the page as it's actively
maintained.

Change-Id: I6e601759f6e26d2c9b94229be953490a8342709a

commit_message:
Add check for redundant import aliases

This adds a pep8 function that will check for redundant import aliases.
Any imports of the forms below will not be allowed.

from x import y as y
import x as x
import x.y as y

Change-Id: Iff90f0172d97bd1d49d54c811a70c8af11776da4

commit_message:
Check for leaked server resource allocations in post_test_hook

The post_test_hook.sh runs in the nova-next CI job. The 1.0.0
version of the osc-placement plugin adds the CLIs to show consumer
resource allocations.

This adds some sanity check code to the post_test_hook.sh script
to look for any resource provider (compute nodes) that have allocations
against them, which shouldn't be the case for successful test runs
where servers are cleaned up properly.

Change-Id: I9801ad04eedf2fede24f3eb104715dcc8e20063d

commit_message:
Remove use of unsupported TEMPEST_SERVICES variable

TEMPEST_SERVICES global variable is not supported
by devstack since long back.
- I380dd20e5ed716a0bdf92aa02c3730359b8136e4
- I9c24705e494689f09a885eb0a640efd50db33fcf

This commit removes the unused TEMPEST_SERVICES setting
Related-Bug: #1743688

Change-Id: I1fe2b6161494648cd8d08860afcab1551e64bae2

commit_message:
Make firewall l2 agent extension more generic

Currently, firewall l2 agent extension is not compatible with LB agent.
This patch make firewall l2 agent extension to be more generic by moving
'request_int_br' to driver side.

Change-Id: Ibcbf55b3cfd960a04b515933c8ede8b4e16cf0b9
Related-Bug: #1752006

commit_message:
Use aio_basekit scenario for OpenSUSE

The aio_basekit scenario is helping the CentOS tests complete
more often and this could help the OpenSUSE tests as well.
This patch adds a non-voting gate test for OpenSUSE using the
aio_basekit scenario. It also disables the existing OpenSUSE
tests since they time out frequently.

Depends-On: Ie1bde8981e46361b611bee0d0be9ff6e5919821b

In the API reference, we'd better to provide more information
about the execute_resize API endpoint:
https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/application-container/#resize-tty-when-execute-command-in-a-container
This endpoint is not designed for end-users. It is designed

execution in a container. Consider documenting this
with a warning message (as what we did for the resize
endpoint: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/application-container/#resize-a-container).

commit_message:
Api-ref: add a warning to execute_resize endpoint

In the API reference, we'd better to provide more information
about the execute_resize API endpoint:
https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/application-container/#resize-tty-when-execute-command-in-a-container
This endpoint is not designed for end-users. It is designed
for UI or CLI to adjust the TTY's size of a command
execution in a container. Consider documenting this
with a warning message (as what we did for the resize
endpoint: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/application-container/#resize-a-container).

Change-Id: I87f33d0d20a1b73f46a67715930b7ac86e256756
Closes-Bug: #1749234

subject: Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-08 17:26:12.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I1ed2e8e85dc558a1990f3fe048eab1e1177ab601
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I1ed2e8e85dc558a1990f3fe048eab1e1177ab601

commit_message:
Fix flakey test_check_delete_headers_sets_delete_at

It was rare (saw it once in 10k runs running locally), but it's
ocassionally blown up in the gate [1]. With this, no fails locally even
after 100k runs.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/11/538011/3/gate/swift-tox-py27/06c06f0/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-02-07_03_29_09_578389

subject: Add new attach check to ensure attached volume is visible
messages: [{'account_id': 17386, 'date': '2018-03-01 11:17:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17386, 'date': '2018-03-01 11:19:43.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nmis-fire'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-01 11:17:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add new attach check to ensure attached volume is visible

There are times when a volume is visible from within an instance but
is no longer readable by the instance. This can happen if the backend
storage device attachment gets inadvertantly disconnected from the
instance.

This change adds a new mechanism in the attach tests to verify that no
only is the volume visible in the instance, but that it is also readable.
The check is sending a command to the instance to have it re-read
the partition table.

Related-Bug: 1752115
Depends-On: Idc5cecffa9129d600c36e332c97f01f1e5ff1f9f

Change-Id: I38b9f4857f65508a2424bf31ceb82003c42804a4
'}]
commit_message:
Add new attach check to ensure attached volume is visible

There are times when a volume is visible from within an instance but
is no longer readable by the instance. This can happen if the backend
storage device attachment gets inadvertantly disconnected from the
instance.

This change adds a new mechanism in the attach tests to verify that no
only is the volume visible in the instance, but that it is also readable.
The check is sending a command to the instance to have it re-read
the partition table.

Related-Bug: 1752115
Depends-On: Idc5cecffa9129d600c36e332c97f01f1e5ff1f9f

Change-Id: I38b9f4857f65508a2424bf31ceb82003c42804a4

commit_message:
Make debug option working for UC heat installer

The debug option can not be picked up from the conf file,
when --use-heat is passed for undercloud install CLI.
Fix unit test to match the default debug=True.

Change-Id: I3c90e4d0cab34dc4bb4f981e87baa5da9f9bd657
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2018-03-01 05:10:56.000000000', 'message': 'Remove --regex from tempest command when running with RDO

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/504345/ has changed the behavior of tempest
when running with --regex and --whitelist-file [1]

after promotion.

were disabled in [3] and hopefully they are more stable now and we can run
without skipping them until we can implement --blacklist-file.

[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547278

commit_message:
Switch to stestr for generating subunit results

* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/504345/ moves the tempest run
  cli to stestr. In order to avoid breakage switch to stestr from
  testr.
* Check for .testresposity and .stestr folder and then use respective
  test runner. It will avoid the breakage in CI.

Change-Id: Ic6c5fb4bdf883708cf4fc08486db7e89e0a76c6a
(cherry picked from commit c5a7236f78dc9a5a81cf58d8f13041cd657b585e)

Remove --regex from tempest command when running with RDO

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/504345/ has changed the behavior of tempest
when running with --regex and --whitelist-file [1]

In order to promote we need to remove this regex option and implement [2] when ready
after promotion.

This patch is removing totally the --regex when not running in UCA. Note these tests
were disabled in [3] and hopefully they are more stable now and we can run
without skipping them until we can implement --blacklist-file.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1751115
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547278
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/461969/

Change-Id: I0dd846a383ed2e1cb4c699a42e618156a9e628b2
(cherry picked from commit 9325150ded93079a819a9800929a643402f3f532)

subject: Conditionally adjust for quoting in comparing MySQL defaults
messages:
[{'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-19 19:17:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-21 20:19:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-21 20:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-21 21:57:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-22 20:36:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-22 20:48:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-02-22 20:55:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-02-22 22:02:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

hmm, bet it was fun discovering how this was breaking... :)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-01 09:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-19 19:17:23.000000000', 'message': 'Conditionally adjust for quoting in comparing MySQL defaults

MariaDB 10.2 appears to not return server defaults with quotes
around integer values which breaks the assumption that we have
to de-quote server default values.  Make the dequoting
a regexp that will pass when the quotes are not present.

Change-Id: Ie5aeffcc3c550673a7fdd82769a315821cebb272
Closes-bug: #1750414
'}, {'created': '2018-02-22 20:55:27.000000000', 'message': 'Conditionally adjust for quoting in comparing MySQL defaults

MariaDB 10.2 appears to not return server defaults with quotes
around integer values which breaks the assumption that we have
to de-quote server default values.  Make the dequoting
a regexp that will pass when the quotes are not present.

Change-Id: Ie5aeffcc3c550673a7fdd82769a315821cebb272
Closes-bug: #1750414
'}]
commit_message:
Conditionally adjust for quoting in comparing MySQL defaults

MariaDB 10.2 appears to not return server defaults with quotes
around integer values which breaks the assumption that we have
to de-quote server default values.  Make the dequoting
a regexp that will pass when the quotes are not present.

Change-Id: Ie5aeffcc3c550673a7fdd82769a315821cebb272
Closes-bug: #1750414

commit_message:
Rearrange doc structure to standard layout

* The document is no longer only for developers, so the title of
  the top page is updated.
* In the current document standard, docs for contributors are
  placed under contributor/.
* Title levels are rearranged to be shown appropriately
  with openstackdocsthems.
* Fixes many sphinx code-block for better rendering.

Change-Id: I36fc80d1c1e5382597099b86df3bbf009ce06902

aiogreen is not part of OpenStack requirements yet. The project is one week old. I would like to discuss the API, before considering it as stable to be able to add it to OpenStack global requirements.

This change should help to discuss the API, ensure that the API fits into OpenStack, and also start to play with trollius coroutines.

I just released aiogreen 0.3 which was written for Oslo Messaging. aiogreen API is the API of asyncio, aiogreen just has two extra functions: link_future() and wrap_future().'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2014-11-23 23:55:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-24 02:50:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Could you avoid trollius on Python 3 and rely on asyncio instead?'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2015-01-16 10:10:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Victor explained on IRC that it's actually better to stick to trollius for compat reasons."}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-01-16 10:19:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> Victor explained on IRC that it's actually better to stick to trollius for compat reasons.

Longer explanation.

There are too many issues with Python 3 right now, so my new executor is only usable with Python 2. I'm trying to fix remaining eventlet issues (related to monkey patching). I have a pending pull request on eventlet:
https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/pull/187

See also this Python 3 fix for Oslo Messaging:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/145241/

It means that Oslo Messaging is not usable yet with Python 3 *and* eventlet (while this new executor is indirectly based on eventlet).

Trollius works on Python 3, even on Python 3.4+. aioeventlet uses asyncio if available, or fallback to trollius.

If you want to use asyncio or trollius depending on the Python version, you cannot write coroutines because asyncio uses "yield from" which raises SyntaxError on Python 2 (Python < 3.3):
http://trollius.readthedocs.org/asyncio.html#differences-between-trollius-and-tulip

I really like writing coroutines, it makes asynchronous programming acceptable :-)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-16 11:39:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-23 21:12:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add a new aiogreen executor

The new executor supports trollius coroutines, explicit asynchronous
programming, in addition to eventlet greenthreads, implicit asynchronous
programming. The aiogreen executor is compatible with the eventlet
executor, it can be used to replace the eventlet executor.

The new executor class is based on the eventlet executor class.

The aiogreen module implements the asyncio API (PEP 3156) on top of
eventlet, see aiogreen documentation:
http://aiogreen.readthedocs.org/

The change adds an unit test with an endpoint implemented as a trollius
coroutine.

Implements: blueprint greenio-executor
Change-Id: I7a78ed998719a703077232726f66d882463b1297

The new executor supports trollius coroutines, explicit asynchronous
programming, in addition to eventlet greenthreads, implicit asynchronous
programming.

The new AsyncioEventletExecutor class is based on the EventletExecutor
class and so it is compatible with it. The aioeventlet executor can be
used to replace the eventlet executor, but it requires an aioeventlet
event loop running in the thread running the executor (which is usually
the main thread). See AsyncioEventletExecutor docstring for an example
how to setup such event loop.

The aioeventlet module implements the asyncio API (PEP 3156) on top of
eventlet, see aioeventlet documentation:
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/

The change adds an unit test with an endpoint implemented as a trollius
coroutine.

commit_message:
Add a new aioeventlet executor

The new executor supports trollius coroutines, explicit asynchronous
programming, in addition to eventlet greenthreads, implicit asynchronous
programming.

The new AsyncioEventletExecutor class is based on the EventletExecutor
class and so it is compatible with it. The aioeventlet executor can be
used to replace the eventlet executor, but it requires an aioeventlet
event loop running in the thread running the executor (usually the main
thread). See AsyncioEventletExecutor docstring for an example how to
setup such event loop.

The aioeventlet module implements the asyncio API (PEP 3156) on top of
eventlet, see aioeventlet documentation:
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/

The change adds an unit test with an endpoint implemented as a trollius
coroutine.

The executor is not supported on Python 3 yet because of eventlet issues
with monkey patching.

Implements: blueprint greenio-executor
Change-Id: I7a78ed998719a703077232726f66d882463b1297

Victor, as I see the oslo.msg driver already have a +2, so, I think that we could include your lib to the global requirements after it'll have another +2 as a sign that the approach is ok."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2015-01-15 09:58:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-01-16 10:21:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Victor, as I see the oslo.msg driver already have a +2, so, I think that we could include your lib to the global requirements after it'll have another +2 as a sign that the approach is ok.

Julien Danjou just approved my Oslo Messaging change, but the merge will fail because of the aioeventlet dependency.

Could you please review (accept!) this change?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2015-01-16 10:25:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2015-01-16 13:54:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

One of the perceived values of OpenStack projects all being in python is that you can move between projects and understand how different parts work.

At this point I'm actually a little concerned that we're running off in a bunch of different directions on how code is going to be written without any clear statement of direction.

This feels like this should be a TC discussion before we start changing the async programming model in projects. Can we get that scheduled on the agenda? I'd be more comfortable +2ing this if there was a statement of direction from the TC that all of OpenStack should convert to asyncio."}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-01-16 14:42:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

"At this point I'm actually a little concerned that we're running off in a bunch of different directions on how code is going to be written without any clear statement of direction."

asyncio was discussed multiple times on the openstack-dev mailing list, and in two blueprints (approved).

I wrote a global roadmap for my project "replace eventlet with asyncio in OpenStack":
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/openstack.html

"This feels like this should be a TC discussion before we start changing the async programming model in projects. Can we get that scheduled on the agenda?"

I added "asyncio" to the agenda of the next meeting (January 20th, 20:00 UTC).

--

A previous version of my Oslo Messaging executor used *greenio* instead of aioeventlet. greenio and aioeventlet are almost the same thing.

The greenio dependency was only added in two days. You even approved it:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/108637/

I don't understand why it's different for aioeventlet.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-27 17:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-01-28 10:40:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2015-01-28 10:41:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-28 11:52:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-12-03 14:47:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add aioeventlet dependency

aioeventlet implements the asyncio API (PEP 3156) on top of eventlet:
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/

aioeventlet works on Python 2.6-3.5 and is distributed under the Apache
License 2.0.

I wrote this project to be able to convert incrementally code from
implicit asynchronous programming (eventlet) to explicit asynchronous
programming (asyncio). The project is part of a blueprint to support
asyncio in OpenStack.

The first step in OpenStack is the following change for Oslo Messaging,
"Add a new aioeventlet executor":
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/136653/

A previous try was based on the greenio module, but greenio doesn't fit
well in OpenStack. For the whole history of the integration of asyncio
into OpenStack, read:
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/openstack.html#history

Implements: blueprint greenio-executor
Change-Id: I58cc28f0a6cba4e17741b1987212e711b20eca54

commit_message:
Add aioeventlet dependency

aioeventlet implements the asyncio API (PEP 3156) on top of eventlet:
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/

aioeventlet works on Python 2.6-3.5 and is distributed under the Apache
License 2.0.

I wrote this project to be able to convert incrementally code from
implicit asynchronous programming (eventlet) to explicit asynchronous
programming (asyncio). The project is part of a blueprint to support
asyncio in OpenStack. Roadmap to replace eventlet with trollius/asyncio:
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/openstack.html#history

The first step in OpenStack is the following change for Oslo Messaging,
"Add a new aioeventlet executor":
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/136653/

A previous try was based on the greenio module, but greenio doesn't fit
well in OpenStack. For the whole history of the integration of asyncio
into OpenStack, read:
http://aioeventlet.readthedocs.org/openstack.html#history

Implements: blueprint greenio-executor
Change-Id: I58cc28f0a6cba4e17741b1987212e711b20eca54

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20421, 'date': '2017-06-14 06:37:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

We should discuss to decide whether we should support the port forwarding on the ip address of the router's external gateway.
We know that we translate instances' ip address to the ip address of the router's external gateway  when we do snat and at the same time we also modify original source port to one new port of the router's external gateway  ip address.
If we support port forwarding on the ip address of the router's external gateway simultaneously，there are chances that the port forwarding dnat rule may conflict with snat records. For example:
SNAT: 2.2.2.3:8800 ---> 139.20.59.24:5680
when there is a flow, router keeps a record that translate back from 139.20.59.24:5680 to 2.2.2.3:8800.
Then we add a port forwarding to 139.20.59.24, something like below:
139.20.59.24:5680 ---> 9.9.9.5:9000. Now the conflict happens."}, {'account_id': 17776, 'date': '2017-08-04 03:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I see that the router gateway port forwarding may be a problem
It would conflict with the SNAT and DNAT.
 unless we explicitly specify the port during port forwarding
 I mean if the Port forwarding is applicable on the router gateway, then we specify the port
 Also we check if the port is already being used by the router in NATing
 if the port is not used in the NAT tables, then we proceed, else we dont'}, {'account_id': 17776, 'date': '2017-08-08 05:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-08-08 05:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified-1

commit_message:
Spec for Port Forwarding

The following spec specifies the Port Forwarding extension
for Floating IPs. And intro a new sub resource into floatingip for port
forwarding support.

Depends-On: If40305044c9dfe0024b64bd3921232bb0a6c9372
Change-Id: Ib2c47b585538bbc067a488e34fd0fc8097314f98
Partial-Bug: #1491317

- Fixes a lot of warnings caused by a newer sphinx 1.6.5 because
  sphinx specified in upper-constraints.txt is used in the new PTI.
- Drop unnecessary [pbrp] warnerrors in favor of warning-is-error.

Change-Id: If40305044c9dfe0024b64bd3921232bb0a6c9372
'}]
commit_message:
Need to follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

For more detials information, please refer to:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

To handle this, this commit changes:

- Introduce doc/requirements.txt
- Update tox.ini [docs] target for developer convenience
- Fixes a lot of warnings caused by a newer sphinx 1.6.5 because
  sphinx specified in upper-constraints.txt is used in the new PTI.
- Drop unnecessary [pbrp] warnerrors in favor of warning-is-error.

Change-Id: If40305044c9dfe0024b64bd3921232bb0a6c9372

commit_message:
Fix docker build job configuration

Docker builds post action failed because the post.yaml was targeted on
a non-existing host. The job has been changed to not publish the
image any more as a zip file as it is easy to reproduce locally and
they are useful only for development or quick starting which is
done locally anyway.

Change-Id: I13babe1d519c25a3889d07d98f383901ccbf6302
Closes-Bug: 1751592

commit_message:
Add clusterrolebinding and clusterrole for elasticsearch-master

The template for elasticsearch-master was missing the clusterrole
and clusterrolebinding. This adds them to bring it in line with
the other templates

Change-Id: I34bc7e889018411b3791c1b7f24d150e1f6a24e5

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-22 16:45:21.000000000', 'message': 'Add UDP per subnet network cidr nat rules

In change I904bbbac383f5fddbe6a88177ef65981d009d28c we added the nat
rules these will default to something like:
 # 140 network cidr nat rules
  "140 ctlplane-subnet cidr nat": {"chain": "FORWARD", "destination": "192.168.24.0/24"}

The problem is that the tripleo::firewall::rule class defaults to proto
'tcp' and hence we will not allow any UDP traffic forwarding.

This can become problematic when the overcloud uses DNS outside any
directly reachable network because if the outside network traffic for
the overcloud is routed and natted through the undercloud, UDP traffic
will be silently dropped.

pcsd is particularly sensitive to DNS timing out, see:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1452561

Change-Id: I21ebdc18fbe55466b2a65c568ceab9b26240557c
Closes-Bug: #1750880

commit_message:
Add proto 'all' per subnet network cidr FORWARD rules in both directions

In change I904bbbac383f5fddbe6a88177ef65981d009d28c we added the
following nat rules, which will default to something like:
 # 140 network cidr nat rules
  "140 ctlplane-subnet cidr nat": {"chain": "FORWARD", "destination": "192.168.24.0/24"}

The problem is that the tripleo::firewall::rule class defaults to proto
'tcp' and hence we will not allow any UDP traffic forwarding and that we
only allow traffic towards the overcloud and not from the overcloud.

This can become problematic when the overcloud uses DNS outside any
directly reachable network because if the outside network traffic for
the overcloud is routed and natted through the undercloud, UDP traffic
will be silently dropped.

pcsd is particularly sensitive to DNS timing out, see:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1452561

Change-Id: I21ebdc18fbe55466b2a65c568ceab9b26240557c
Closes-Bug: #1750880

- gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-upstream-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/74/481674/2/check/gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-upstream-ubuntu-xenial/6cfb16e/ : SUCCESS in 40m 32s'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2017-07-10 14:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Firstly, the -1 is not for bad code - it's all good :) However, I'm beginning to think this necessary. Reproducing my comments from IRC today below:

I've been playing around with Sphinx trying to find a way to make this an extension. mordred was dead right in his comment that "the initial sphinx constructor fails when project and version are missing so it doesn't make it as far as extensions" :( The earliest "event" we can hook into is 'builder-inited', which comes way too late in the process, so I went adding a 'config-inited' event that we could use in Sphinx 1.7 or whatnot. However, I stopped when I thought about why readthedocs.org don't have this issue. They seem to automatically version and name docs without issues. This looks to because they store config _outside_ of conf.py, and simply pass it in as sphinx-build flags

This is something we can also do with the setuptools command (build_sphinx). My thought is that we modify the doc build jobs to start passing in these flags and completely override ignore whatever's in conf.py. It's minimal effort and doesn't require rolling anything out to the projects now or ever. We just tell folks to set 'project', 'version' and 'copyright' to something generic _if they want to_. This will result in local builds that don't look like the gate, but that's no different to lots of other projects out there, and really not something we need to worry about IMO.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-12-12 21:26:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Firstly, the -1 is not for bad code - it's all good :) However, I'm
 > beginning to think this necessary. Reproducing my comments from IRC
 > today below:
 > 
 > I've been playing around with Sphinx trying to find a way to make
 > this an extension. mordred was dead right in his comment that "the
 > initial sphinx constructor fails when project and version are
 > missing so it doesn't make it as far as extensions" :( The earliest
 > "event" we can hook into is 'builder-inited', which comes way too
 > late in the process, so I went adding a 'config-inited' event that
 > we could use in Sphinx 1.7 or whatnot. However, I stopped when I
 > thought about why readthedocs.org don't have this issue. They seem
 > to automatically version and name docs without issues. This looks
 > to because they store config _outside_ of conf.py, and simply pass
 > it in as sphinx-build flags
 > 
 > This is something we can also do with the setuptools command
 > (build_sphinx). My thought is that we modify the doc build jobs to
 > start passing in these flags and completely override ignore
 > whatever's in conf.py. It's minimal effort and doesn't require
 > rolling anything out to the projects now or ever. We just tell
 > folks to set 'project', 'version' and 'copyright' to something
 > generic _if they want to_. This will result in local builds that
 > don't look like the gate, but that's no different to lots of other
 > projects out there, and really not something we need to worry about
 > IMO.
 > 
 > Thoughts?

I like the idea of passing information to the build.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-01-09 12:03:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

This has been around for long enough and we're able to configure this stuff via command line arguments (which is what we're doing in the gate). I don't think we need to provide this API at this stage"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-01 09:35:07.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning due to my -2s. Feel free to reopen if you think I'm talking rubbish :)"}]

commit_message:
Add two helper functions for setting sphinx config

As a step towards getting out of the magic build_sphinx business,
provide simple helper methods that do the conf override work pbr was
doing.

Change-Id: Ibf6630a666c441422ee9fbaf2afb1bcb129187be

commit_message:
Grab package name from setup.cfg

There's no need to have a project pass this in. We're always in a source
directory. The value is always in setup.cfg.

Change-Id: If4c59650a219167e49ce0befa967f9a5bf3851c6

[{'created': '2017-07-07 15:38:36.000000000', 'message': "Add openstackdocstheme support and infer names

All but two of the openstackdocstheme settings can be inferred by files
that pbr can know to be around. Infer them, and set the
openstackdocstheme settings.

Note - this is likely not the best way to go about this long-term. Since
we're trying to import openstackdocstheme - we'll have the object if
it's around. That means we could add a companion method in
openstackdocstheme that takes globals, project_name, bug_name, bug_tag
and repo_name and sets whatever options it needs to set.

Change-Id: I00ad9b207a77b95ea29bd52bee66cf828c8f23eb
"}, {'created': '2017-07-07 17:22:07.000000000', 'message': "Add openstackdocstheme support and infer names

All but two of the openstackdocstheme settings can be inferred by files
that pbr can know to be around. Infer them, and set the
openstackdocstheme settings.

Note - this is likely not the best way to go about this long-term. Since
we're trying to import openstackdocstheme - we'll have the object if
it's around. That means we could add a companion method in
openstackdocstheme that takes globals, project_name, bug_name, bug_tag
and repo_name and sets whatever options it needs to set.

Change-Id: I00ad9b207a77b95ea29bd52bee66cf828c8f23eb
"}]
commit_message:
Add openstackdocstheme support and infer names

All but two of the openstackdocstheme settings can be inferred by files
that pbr can know to be around. Infer them, and set the
openstackdocstheme settings.

Note - this is likely not the best way to go about this long-term. Since
we're trying to import openstackdocstheme - we'll have the object if
it's around. That means we could add a companion method in
openstackdocstheme that takes globals, project_name, bug_name, bug_tag
and repo_name and sets whatever options it needs to set.

Change-Id: I00ad9b207a77b95ea29bd52bee66cf828c8f23eb

commit_message:
Add htmlhelp and latex options

The LaTeX option in particular is set incorrectly in pretty much
everyone's conf.py. Almost nothing in OpenStack is written by "the
OpenStack Foundation".

Let's get rid of the copy-pasta.

Change-Id: I86e0c662fa23487131c18261b4a0b4108e76bcac

commit_message:
Add functional tests to ensure BDM removal on delete

In certain cases, such as when an instance fails to be scheduled,
the volume may already have an attachment created (or the volume
has been reserved in the old flows).

This patch adds a test to check that these volume attachments
are deleted and removed once the instance has been deleted. It
also adds some functionality to allow checking when an volume
has been reserved in the Cinder fixtures.

This backported patch drops the tests for the new-attach flow
for Cinder as it does not exist in Pike.

Change-Id: I85cc3998fbcde30eefa5429913ca287246d51255
Related-Bug: #1404867
(cherry picked from commit 20edeb362327ea9448d38b6e2bcb03e0a71060d0)

commit_message:
Parameterize expirer unit tests

To prepare for implementing general task queue mode to expirer,
this patch parameterize expirer unit tests' conf, expected log lines,
task queue status, and others.
The parameterized unit tests will make expirer's general task queue
patch [1] more smaller.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/517389

Change-Id: Ie16dfdc5966d1438ff7dad30a0515ca04c3311fc

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 17:16:27.000000000', 'message': "Fix and update compute schedulers config guide

There were several things wrong with this doc since the migration
in-tree in pike, which are handled here:

- Updated options to use the current names.
- Any mention of the periodic_task_interval option is removed
  since this doc is really about the FilterScheduler, and the
  periodic task interval is only used by the CachingScheduler to
  cache and refresh hosts, something the FilterScheduler doesn't do.
  The note about service_down_time is already covered in the help
  text for the periodic_task_interval option.
- Removed a broken (and oddly placed) link to the block storage
  docs; it's unclear why the compute scheduler docs need to randomly
  link to the block storage docs for schedluing (maybe that was
  super legacy from the nova-volume days).
- Fixed a broken link to the 'evacuate instances' docs.

This change does not get into details for the individual filters
or weighers, only the overview and filter scheduler description.

Change-Id: Ie5bb9781e1997ad12521b5df5245a78b587a4a20
Closes-Bug: #1749235
"}]
commit_message:
Fix and update compute schedulers config guide

There were several things wrong with this doc since the migration
in-tree in pike, which are handled here:

- Updated options to use the current names.
- Any mention of the periodic_task_interval option is removed
  since this doc is really about the FilterScheduler, and the
  periodic task interval is only used by the CachingScheduler to
  cache and refresh hosts, something the FilterScheduler doesn't do.
  The note about service_down_time is already covered in the help
  text for the periodic_task_interval option.
- Removed a broken (and oddly placed) link to the block storage
  docs; it's unclear why the compute scheduler docs need to randomly
  link to the block storage docs for schedluing (maybe that was
  super legacy from the nova-volume days).
- Fixed a broken link to the 'evacuate instances' docs.

This change does not get into details for the individual filters
or weighers, only the overview and filter scheduler description.

Change-Id: Ie5bb9781e1997ad12521b5df5245a78b587a4a20
Closes-Bug: #1749235

commit_message:
Switch to stestr for generating subunit results

* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/504345/ moves the tempest run
  cli to stestr. In order to avoid breakage switch to stestr from
  testr.
* Check for .testresposity and .stestr folder and then use respective
  test runner. It will avoid the breakage in CI.

Change-Id: Ic6c5fb4bdf883708cf4fc08486db7e89e0a76c6a
(cherry picked from commit c5a7236f78dc9a5a81cf58d8f13041cd657b585e)

subject: Enable more hacking-extensions
messages:
[{'account_id': 22255, 'date': '2018-02-01 02:42:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-02-01 11:50:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Before adding new hacking checks into lib, we need to go through each consuming project (using stable/branches) that's using lib's hacking check factory [1] and ensure these new checks don't break them. Otherwise when these new enabled checks land and are released with lib, those projects will be broken with pep8.


Also please be aware that neutron does not yet use lib's hacking checks. So with that in mind, this change would not enable them for neutron.


[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=local-check-factory%20%3D%20neutron_lib.hacking.checks&i=nope&files=&repos="}, {'account_id': 22255, 'date': '2018-03-01 07:33:49.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 02:42:50.000000000', 'message': "Enable more hacking-extensions

This patch enable extensions:
-[H204] Use assert(Not)Equal to check for equality.
-[H205] Use assert(Greater|Less)(Equal) for comparison.
-[H106] Don't put vim configuration in source files
-[H203] Use assertIs(Not)None to check for None

Change-Id: Ic18d895140d35c59ee4d5b70980212465551d797
"}]
commit_message:
Enable more hacking-extensions

This patch enable extensions:
-[H204] Use assert(Not)Equal to check for equality.
-[H205] Use assert(Greater|Less)(Equal) for comparison.
-[H106] Don't put vim configuration in source files
-[H203] Use assertIs(Not)None to check for None

Change-Id: Ic18d895140d35c59ee4d5b70980212465551d797

commit_message:
Do not have to mention ssl_ca_cert in vim config file (server)

This patch along with  another patch on the tacker client
will remove the need to mention ssl_ca_cert in the vim
configuration file.

Tacker client patch: https://review.openstack.org/546578

Change-Id: I362c40e8b2a606e3b28d368a95e74ee5ea306241

subject: Do not complete MongoDBContext with out replset
messages: [{'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-24 21:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-02-28 08:41:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-02-28 09:19:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-02-28 17:25:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-03-01 06:56:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2\n\nLGTM'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-24 21:13:48.000000000', 'message': 'Do not complete MongoDBContext with out replset

When there are multiple mongodb peers but replset has not yet been set
on the relation, do not complete the MongoDBContext. This causes the
template to be rendered incorrectly and leads to the following error:

ERROR ceilometer ValueError: Port must be an integer between 0 and
65535:

Closes-Bug: #1750639
Change-Id: Ifb9424ac5e175d788fa21de0ee332c0a13e61a9f
'}]
commit_message:
Do not complete MongoDBContext with out replset

When there are multiple mongodb peers but replset has not yet been set
on the relation, do not complete the MongoDBContext. This causes the
template to be rendered incorrectly and leads to the following error:

ERROR ceilometer ValueError: Port must be an integer between 0 and
65535:

Closes-Bug: #1750639
Change-Id: Ifb9424ac5e175d788fa21de0ee332c0a13e61a9f
